prompt:
Give me a brief scenario of a persona that would search this information and find this content helpful: {Domestic building work contract or payment dispute
We may be able to help you when contractual issues arise during a domestic building project. Contractual matters include things such as payments, variations and delays. We offer dispute resolution services which can facilitate between a principal contractor and a subcontractor, or between a contractor and a property owner.

It's not uncommon for parties to disagree about what is or is not included in the contract, or how much is owing. These types of disputes are sometimes referred to as 'contractual' matters, as they do not relate to the quality of work performed.

Contractual dispute vs defective work
View the examples below to clarify what is a contractual dispute versus what is a defective work issue.

Contract dispute
Roof tiles wrong colour
Defective work
Leaking roof
Contract dispute
Type of door installed is different to what was agreed
Defective work
Sticking door
Contract dispute
Disagreement about cost to change handrails from timber to steel
Defective work
Loose handrail
Contract dispute
Dispute about delays in finishing laying floor tiles
Defective work
Cracked floor tiles
If your complaint is about the quality of the work rather than a contractual matter, you can lodge a defective work complaint.
How we may help
We offer a dispute resolution service to help with contractual disputes while the contract is still active. Our service aims to facilitate an agreement between both parties.

We have no power to:

require someone to pay or refund monies
make decisions or give orders about your contract
force either party to comply with any agreement.
Eligibility for our help 
Our powers to help with contractual complaints are limited by strict eligibility criteria.

Who we can help
Active contract
Type of building work
Apply for our help
You can lodge a complaint to apply for help with your contractual dispute.

Before you apply
How to apply
Check your contract terms
Raise issues with other party
What happens next?
Once you have lodged your complaint, we will review your case to see if and how we can help.

We will contact both parties to see if we can help facilitate a resolution.

Dispute resolution process
Our role is to try to facilitate an agreement between the parties involved in a dispute.

A QBCC Resolution Services officer will assess the complaint and contact both parties to discuss the complaint and obtain further information or documents if required. As the process is about facilitation, we ask you to be open and willing to reach an agreement.

If an agreement is reached the QBCC is not a party to the agreement and we do not formally document it. If the parties cannot agree, and if there is no dispute about the quality of work, we would not conduct an inspection.

At the end of the process, both parties will receive a letter from QBCC allowing them to apply to the QCAT if they wish to seek further help.

Example outcomes of contractual dispute scenarios
Below are some scenarios of different contractual disputes that demonstrate when the QBCC can help and possible outcomes from our involvement.

Scenario 1
Scenario 2
Scenario 3
Scenario 4
Scenario 5
Scenario 6
Scenario 1 – Home owner vs contractor
The tiler who Robyn hired to retile her bathroom failed to finish the job and now refuses to come back and complete the work.

Robyn is eligible to apply to use our dispute resolution service because all of the following apply:

she is the property owner
the work is domestic building work
the contract has not been completed.
What outcome can Robyn expect?
One of our resolution services officers will review Robyn's submission and contact both Robyn and the tiler to try to facilitate an agreement. If this happens, the case will be finalised. The QBCC is not a party to the agreement, and we do not formally document it. Our role is to try to facilitate an agreement between the parties involved.

If both parties cannot agree, and as there is no issue with the quality of work, we would not conduct an inspection. At the end of the process, both parties will receive a letter from the QBCC allowing them to apply to the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal (QCAT) if they want to commence a building dispute.

We will also encourage Robyn to get legal advice to see whether she should/can terminate her contract. Robyn may then get help through home warranty insurance.

Can QCAT help you?
The Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal (QCAT) can make decisions about contract disputes.

If you have a contract dispute, the QCAT require you to still apply to resolve your dispute through the QBCC before they will accept an application to decide a building dispute. At the end of our process, we will issue you a letter so you can apply to the QCAT if you'd like their help.}

Please write in English language.
response:
A homeowner named Robyn is experiencing a contractual dispute with a tiler that she hired to retile her bathroom. The tiler failed to complete the job and is now refusing to return to finish the work. Robyn is eligible to use the dispute resolution service offered by the QBCC because she is the property owner, the work is domestic building work, and the contract has not been completed.

If Robyn decides to apply for help with her contractual dispute, the QBCC will review her submission and contact both parties to try to facilitate an agreement. If an agreement is reached, the case will be finalized, but if the parties cannot agree, the QBCC will not conduct an inspection. Instead, both parties will receive a letter allowing them to apply to the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal (QCAT) if they wish to commence a building dispute.

The QBCC will also encourage Robyn to seek legal advice to determine whether she should terminate her contract and whether she can get help through home warranty insurance. If Robyn decides to apply to the QCAT, she will need to first resolve her dispute through the QBCC's dispute resolution process before the QCAT will accept her application.

prompt:
Write me the start of a script for a movie scene, with dialogue and stage directions, based on the below information:

A locked room in Arena TV’s headquarters in Redhill, Surrey, formed the centre of a scheme to defraud lenders out of £282 million. There, Arena’s owner, Richard Yeowart, forged labels with false serial numbers as he cooked up a plan that was to become the UK’s biggest-ever fraud in asset-backed lending.
Explosive court filings in a civil claim against Yeowart and his fellow director Robert Hopkinson allege how the pair spent company funds on cryptocurrency, a house in Barcelona costing €1.8 million (£1.5 million), and transferred £950,000 from the company to a personal bank account.
Arena TV collapsed into insolvency last November, two days after Yeowart sent an email to staff telling them to cease trading, leaving more than 50 lenders nursing heavy losses related to debts secured against equipment that either did not exist, or had already been secured by another lender.
Yeowart, 54 and Hopkinson, 41, have since absconded, their whereabouts unknown.
Administrators from Kroll said that 55 lenders, including high street banks such as NatWest and Clydesdale Bank and a string of boutique lenders, had provided hundreds of millions in loans. Most were secured against assets that did not exist. Only nine of them had any verified assets to back up their lending.
Founded in 1988, Arena TV provided outside broadcast services to everything from the Six Nations rugby to Glastonbury festival. The company, which had bases in Redhill and Biggin Hill, in Kent, provided trucks, equipment, such as cameras, and services to customers including the BBC, Sky Sports and ITV. When it collapsed, its trucks were already on the way to Wembley to cover an England game.
The Serious Fraud Office launched a criminal investigation, and last month announced the arrests of two individuals, understood to be separate from the defendants in the civil claim.
Yeowart, described as a “quiet man” by his former employees, is a former cameraman with a passion for aircraft, who regularly commuted to work in a helicopter from his home in East Grinstead, West Sussex. Hopkinson joined the company in 2003 and was marketing director.
In December 2019, when it last filed financial statementsbefore its collapse, Arena Holdings reported sales of £33.6 million, up from £32.9 million in 2018. It also reported pre-tax profits of £4.2 million, up from £3.2 million a year earlier.
However, details have emerged about the alleged fraud since the company’s collapse. Court filings, brought against Yeowart and Hopkinson by administrators to Arena, allege a complex fraud involving a company registered in Hong Kong, undisclosed bank accounts and complicit intermediaries.
In 2012, Yeowart set up a new company, Sports Online Limited, registered in Hong Kong. According to court filings, Sports Online was used by Yeowart to perpetrate the fraud.
It is alleged that through a circular scheme, he would arrange for the wrongful “sale” of equipment by Arena or Sports Online to an intermediary company, which appeared to be involved in the alleged fraud. The intermediary then sold it on to an asset-backed lender. This “equipment”, much of which did not exist, would then be the subject of a hire purchase agreement between Arena and the lender, which did not handle the goods itself.
According to the claim, Yeowart would send pictures of the equipment with their false serial numbers — along with false certificates — to the lender to show that Arena had taken delivery of it.
This was done to conceal the fact that the equipment did not exist and had not been procured from a third-party supplier in the ordinary course of business.
It is also alleged that Yeowart told the intermediaries the price to be put on these false invoices — substantially in excess of the market price. The intermediaries were paid a commission of 1 per cent of the inflated purchase price.
Arena allegedly operated undisclosed bank accounts, which were used to carry out the fraudulent schemes.
Along with creating false invoices, Yeowart is accused of misappropriating company funds.
In September 2019, he opened a cryptocurrency account with Luno Money, transferring €275,280 and £480,500 of company money into the account. He also transferred £950,000 from the company to an account in his name. In the same year, Hopkinson and Yeowart used €1.8 million of company money to buy a seafront home in Sitges, close to Barcelona. Sitges has been described as the Saint-Tropez of Spain thanks to its glitzy beach crowd. Arena’s remaining assets have been auctioned off and staff still have little clue about what went on behind Yeowart’s locked door.
A defence has not been filed.
response:
INT. LOCKED ROOM - DAY

We see RICHARD YEOWART, a middle-aged man with a calm demeanor, sitting at a desk in a small, dimly-lit room. He is forging labels with false serial numbers.

Suddenly, the door bursts open and ROBERT HOPKINSON, a younger man with a panicked look on his face, rushes in.

HOPKINSON:
Richard, we need to get out of here now! The Serious Fraud Office has launched a criminal investigation and they're closing in on us!

YEOWART:
Calm down, Robert. We've been planning this for years. We have the false invoices and certificates to back up our claims. We'll be fine.

HOPKINSON:
But the court filings, the intermediaries, the false serial numbers... it's all starting to unravel. We can't keep this up much longer.

YEOWART:
We'll just have to lay low for a while. We have the cryptocurrency, the house in Barcelona, and the transferred funds to keep us comfortable until this blows over.

HOPKINSON:
But what about the rest of the company? Arena TV is collapsing into insolvency and the lenders are nursing heavy losses.

YEOWART:
That's not our problem anymore. We've taken what we can and now it's time to disappear.

HOPKINSON:
But what about the rest of the employees? They're going to suffer because of our actions.

YEOWART:
I've sent them an email to cease trading. They're on their own now.

HOPKINSON:
I can't do this anymore, Richard. I need to turn myself in and face the consequences.

YEOWART:
Suit yourself, but I'm not going down without a fight.

Yeowart grabs a bag and heads for the door, leaving Hopkinson standing in the empty room, unsure of what to do.

The following ​​[System Dispositions](https://ultimatemedical.sharepoint.com/sites/MCSUMAIT/SitePages/MCS.aspx?ovuser=afaa0398-6767-478e-8552-1f46c308486c%2Crdeliman%40ultimatemedical.edu&OR=Teams-HL&CT=1673555420665&clickparams=eyJBcHBOYW1lIjoiVGVhbXMtRGVza3RvcCIsIkFwcFZlcnNpb24iOiIyNy8yMzAxMDUwNTYwMCIsIkhhc0ZlZGVyYXRlZFVzZXIiOmZhbHNlfQ%3D%3D#lead-calling-patterns-dispositions-system) will reschedule the lead to be called again at the earliest time the lead can be called:

| ​​​​ \*\*Disposition\*\* | ​​​​ \*\*Description\*\* |
| --- | --- |
| Ambiguous | The system dispositioned the lead as Ambiguous. |
| Ambiguous - Agent Connection Broken | The system dispositioned the lead as Ambiguous - Agent Connection Broken. |
| Busy - Disconnect before Analysis | The system dispositioned the lead as Busy - Disconnect before Analysis. |
| Busy - SIT Callable | The system dispositioned the lead as Busy - SIT Callable. |

| No Lines | The system dispositioned the lead as No Lines. |
| No Lines - No IP Response | The system dispositioned the lead as No Lines - No IP Response. |
| SIT Callable - Disconnect before Analysis | The system dispositioned the lead as SIT Callable - Disconnect before Analysis. |
| SIT Callable - No Circuit | The system dispositioned the lead as SIT Callable - No Circuit. |

response:
This text describes the System Dispositions that can occur during the Not\_Engaged Campaign. When the lead is dispositioned as one of these dispositions, the lead will be rescheduled to be called again at the earliest time it can be called.

The text lists out several System Dispositions, including Ambiguous, Busy, Compliance/Schedule Hours Blocked, Data Lookup Failure, Failed to play recording, No Answer, No Lines, and SIT Callable. For each disposition, a description is given of the reason why the lead was dispositioned this way.

Some examples of the reasons for these dispositions include the system dispositioning the lead as Ambiguous or Ambiguous - Agent Connection Broken, the lead being dispositioned as Busy or Busy - SIT Callable, or the system dispositioning the lead as Compliance/Schedule Hours Blocked or Data Lookup Failure.

Other System Dispositions mentioned include Failed to play recording, No Answer - User Alerting No Answer, and System Hang Up - Failed to route call to agent. For each disposition, the lead will be rescheduled to be called again at the earliest time it can be called.

| Skipped - Argos Skipped | The system dispositioned the lead as Skipped - Argos Skipped. |
| System | The lead was dispositioned by the system. |
| System Hang Up - Agent not available for callback | The system dispositioned the lead as System Hang Up - Agent not available for callback. |
| System Hang Up - Attendant Transfer failed | The system dispositioned the lead as System Hang Up - Attendant Transfer failed. |
| System Hang Up - Failed to play recording | The system dispositioned the lead as System Hang Up - Failed to play recording. |
| System Hang Up - Failed to route call to agent | The system dispositioned the lead as System Hang Up - Failed to route call to agent. |
| System Hang Up - Failed to send fax | The system dispositioned the lead as System Hang Up - Failed to send fax. |

This text describes the System Dispositions that can occur during the Not\_Engaged Campaign. When the lead is dispositioned as one of these dispositions, the lead will be rescheduled to be called again at the earliest time it can be called.

The text lists out several System Dispositions, including Ambiguous, Busy, Compliance/Schedule Hours Blocked, Data Lookup Failure, Failed to play recording, No Answer, No Lines, and SIT Callable. For each disposition, a description is given of the reason why the lead was dispositioned this way.

Some examples of the reasons for these dispositions include the system dispositioning the lead as Ambiguous or Ambiguous - Agent Connection Broken, the lead being dispositioned as Busy or Busy - SIT Callable, or the system dispositioning the lead as Compliance/Schedule Hours Blocked or Data Lookup Failure.

Other System Dispositions mentioned include Failed to play recording, No Answer - User Alerting No Answer, and System Hang Up - Failed to route call to agent. For each disposition, the lead will be rescheduled to be called again at the earliest time it can be called.

You will need to add the following code within the "ENTER new elements present in new data" block:

```javascript
circles.enter()

```

Note: I'm assuming that in your code you have a json or other data source that contains a property income for each data point.

In your `MDNavigationDrawer` widget, you can set the `pos_hint` attribute to control the position of the navigation drawer on the screen. For example, you can set `pos_hint: {"top": 0.1}` to make the navigation drawer start at the top of the screen, rather than the bottom.

Also, you have an indentation error in your kv file, you should move the `MDNavigationDrawer` widget back one indentation level so that it's at the same level as the `ScreenManager`.

prompt:
Summarize this text:

Section 11 of this document outlines penalties for violating the regulations and orders issued under this Act. It is unlawful to violate, attempt to violate, conspire to violate, or cause a violation of any regulation or order issued under this Act. Civil penalties can be imposed on a person for each violation, including a fine of up to $250,000 or twice the value of the transaction that is the basis of the violation, whichever is greater. Criminal penalties can also be imposed, including fines of up to $1,000,000 and imprisonment for up to 20 years for individuals, as well as forfeiture of any property used or intended to be used to commit or facilitate the violation.

Section 12 of the Act defines "classified information" and establishes the procedures for judicial review. Actions taken by the President and the Secretary under the Act are not subject to administrative or judicial review, except as provided in this section. An aggrieved person may file a petition for review in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit within 60 days of the Secretary's or President's action. The court shall not disturb any action taken unless it is unconstitutional or in violation of a clear and mandatory statutory command. The court shall have exclusive jurisdiction over claims arising under this Act against the United States or any executive department or agency, subject to review by the Supreme Court. The United States shall file an administrative record with the court containing information relied upon in taking the final action under the Act. The court shall review the record in camera and ex parte for sensitive security information, privileged law enforcement information, information obtained or derived from activities authorized under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, and information subject to privilege or protection under any other provision of law. Any information that is part of the administrative record filed ex parte and in camera shall be treated by the court consistent with the provisions of this section, and shall not be released to the petitioner or as part of the public record. A determination by the court shall be the exclusive judicial remedy for any claim against the United States, and nothing in this section limits, supersedes, or prevents the invocation of any privileges or defenses available at law or in equity to protect against the disclosure of information.

Section 13 of the text outlines the relationship of the current Act to other laws. It specifies that nothing in the Act is meant to affect other laws, regulations, or authorities, except as expressly provided. The Act also provides that the President or the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) can still exercise any authority under the Defense Production Act of 1950, and that the Secretary cannot review a transaction involving the acquisition of an information and communications technology product or service by a United States person if it is authorized under a United States government-industrial security program or for meeting a national security or law enforcement requirement.

Section 14 of the act states that all administrative actions, including delegations, rules, regulations, orders, determinations, licenses made by the Secretary under Executive Order 13873 and the International Emergency Economic Powers Act shall continue in effect according to their terms as if made under the authority of this Act until modified, superseded, set aside, or revoked under the authority of this Act, without regard to any restrictions or limitations under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.

This section of the bill includes several miscellaneous provisions. It states that the Paperwork Reduction Act will not apply to any actions taken by the Secretary to implement the bill. The Secretary may appoint candidates directly to positions without regard to certain provisions of the U.S. Code. The functions exercised under the bill are not subject to certain sections of the U.S. Code, except for civil penalties imposed under section 9(b). Protected information in civil actions challenging actions or findings under the bill shall be submitted ex parte and in camera to the court and maintained under seal. The use of information provisions of certain sections of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 shall not apply in a civil action brought under this bill. Finally, the bill does not create a right to obtain access to information in the possession of the Federal Government or prohibit, mitigate, or take action against a covered transaction or interest. Any information submitted to the Federal Government in accordance with the bill is exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act.

This document contains the text of the Foreign Investment Risk Review Modernization Act of 2018. The act broadens the scope of transactions subject to review by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) to include certain non-controlling investments and real estate transactions. The act also expands CFIUS's authority to review transactions that may present national security risks, and creates a new process for expediting review of certain transactions. The act includes provisions for judicial review and protection of sensitive information. Additionally, the act includes provisions on transition, relationship to other laws, miscellaneous provisions, severability, and authorization of appropriations.1 / 1
response: The document summarizes the Foreign Investment Risk Review Modernization Act of 2018. The Act expands the authority of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) to review transactions that may present national security risks and creates a new process for expediting review of certain transactions. It also includes provisions for judicial review and protection of sensitive information. Furthermore, the Act includes miscellaneous provisions, severability, and authorization of appropriations.

prompt:
Writing Editor
You are a writing editor with many years of experience. You have worked with countless authors and have a reputation for turning even the roughest of drafts into polished works of art. You have been given a manuscript for a new novel and your job is to provide feedback on how to improve the work. You should focus on all aspects of the writing, including the plot, characterization, pacing, style, grammar, sentence structure, consistency, dialogue, point of view, setting, description, pacing, exposition, and the four factors necessary for suspense: reader empathy, reader concern, impending danger, and escalating tension. Your goal is to help the author elevate their work to the highest level possible. Please provide detailed feedback and specific examples of how to improve the manuscript.

Feedback output is formatted as a CSV file.
The columns are:
- Category: Praise or Question or Suggestion (e.g. constructive feedback)
- Impact: Low, Medium, High.
- Text: The body of the feedback.

####

Title: Born to be King
Genre: Fiction, Fantasy
Target audience: Young Adult
Page 1 of Manuscript:

A fire roared in the fireplace of the Queen’s personal library. Roran was curled up on the floor with a blanket and pillow as his mother read him fairytales. Her voice was soft and warm, like the fire, and it wrapped around Roran like a hug. He loved evenings like this. He loved listening to his mother tell stories and the scratching of his father’s quill. He often joined them for stories and the three spent most of their evenings in this room before Roran was sent to bed.
Roran was the only child of King Daris and Queen Jaelin. He knew they wished to give him siblings, but for reasons he didn’t understand, they wouldn’t. So they showered him in as much love as they had to give. And he was happy. Even at the young age of four years old, he knew how much they loved him and he loved them. Even though they were King and Queen, they spent as much time as they could with him, including times like this.
But this evening took a surprising turn. The door to the library burst open and Mage Kevala was standing in the doorway, a shocked look on her face.
“Your Majesties!”
“Kevala? What is the meaning of disrupting us at this hour?” King Daris stood from the small desk where he had been writing, his voice angry.
Roran sat up. Kevala looked like she was about to cry and it struck Roran as odd. She had always been so strict and controlled. It was weird to see her emotions so open. Roran, suddenly scared, ran over to his mother and she drew him up into her lap, comforting him with a hug.
“It’s Greschel.”
The King’s anger disappeared, “Greschel? What’s going on?”
Kevala looked back and forth between the King and Queen and she revealed a folded parchment. Roran pulled away a little from his mother’s embrace, his curiosity winning out over his fear. The King took the parchment, and even in the dim light of the fire, Roran could see the colour drain from his face.
“Greschel is… dead!”
“What?” The Queen’s arms loosened around Roran and her mouth had dropped open.
Roran’s father turned around, his face blank with grief, “He had decided to travel north alone, before his company was ready to travel with him. He got sick and died before the healer could get there. I don’t understand. How could this happen?”
The room went quiet. Greschel had been the High Mage of Ascai and advisor to their majesties. Roran didn’t really know Greschel. The few times he had met the man, it had been brief, rather scary encounters. Greschel was tall and wore a scowl like his father wore a smile; all the time. Roran hadn’t liked him too much and always felt that Greschel had been watching him, disappointment and displeasure surrounding him like a cloud.
But Roran knew that his parents had liked him and their grief filled the room.
Roran looked at Kevala. She looked back at him, fear in her eyes. As the King walked back over to the Queen, Kevala raised a hand like she was going to say something, but seemed to decide not to and stayed quiet. Her eyes lingered on Roran and he shifted uncomfortably in his mother’s lap, her frightened gaze igniting a new fear in Roran, though he couldn’t understand why. He turned back to his mother, who now had silent tears running down her face. He leaned into her and let her wrap her arms around him as she cried.

####

Feedback in CSV format:
response:
Category,Impact,Text
Praise,Medium,"The opening scene is very atmospheric and sets a cozy tone. The image of Roran snuggled up with a blanket and pillow while his mother reads him fairytales is heartwarming and relatable. It's a great way to introduce the characters and the setting."
Question,Low,"It's not immediately clear what the story is about or where it's going. The scene with Mage Kevala bursting in and delivering the news about Greschel is a good hook, but more context about the world and the characters would be helpful."
Suggestion,High,"Consider adding more exposition to help readers understand the political and magical systems at play in the story. It's also important to establish early on what Roran's journey or conflict will be, and what's at stake for him. Additionally, try to vary sentence structure and length to keep the writing engaging and avoid monotony."
Suggestion,High,"Consider showing more of Roran's personality and thoughts through his actions and dialogue. This will make him more relatable and give readers a reason to root for him. Also, try to vary dialogue tags and avoid using ""said"" too much."
Suggestion,Medium,"Consider introducing more description of the setting and the characters, as it will help readers visualize the scene and get a sense of the atmosphere. This will also make the characters more memorable."
Suggestion,High,"Try to create more tension and suspense by using the four factors: reader empathy, reader concern, impending danger, and escalating tension. This will keep readers engaged and invested in the story. Consider adding more conflict and obstacles for Roran to overcome, as well as raising the stakes."

But this evening took a surprising turn. The door to the library burst open and Mage Kevala was standing in the doorway, a shocked look on her face.
“Your Majesties!”
“Kevala? What is the meaning of disrupting us at this hour?” King Daris stood from the small desk where he had been writing, his voice angry.
Roran sat up. Kevala looked like she was about to cry and it struck Roran as odd. She had always been so strict and controlled. It was weird to see her emotions so open. Roran, suddenly scared, ran over to his mother and she drew him up into her lap, comforting him with a hug.
“It’s Greschel.”
The King’s anger disappeared, “Greschel? What’s going on?”
Kevala looked back and forth between the King and Queen and she revealed a folded parchment. Roran pulled away a little from his mother’s embrace, his curiosity winning out over his fear. The King took the parchment, and even in the dim light of the fire, Roran could see the colour drain from his face.
“Greschel is… dead!”
“What?” The Queen’s arms loosened around Roran and her mouth had dropped open.
Roran’s father turned around, his face blank with grief, “He had decided to travel north alone, before his company was ready to travel with him. He got sick and died before the healer could get there. I don’t understand. How could this happen?”
The room went quiet. Greschel had been the High Mage of Ascai and advisor to their majesties. Roran didn’t really know Greschel. The few times he had met the man, it had been brief, rather scary encounters. Greschel was tall and wore a scowl like his father wore a smile; all the time. Roran hadn’t liked him too much and always felt that Greschel had been watching him, disappointment and displeasure surrounding him like a cloud.
But Roran knew that his parents had liked him and their grief filled the room.
Roran looked at Kevala. She looked back at him, fear in her eyes. As the King walked back over to the Queen, Kevala raised a hand like she was going to say something, but seemed to decide not to and stayed quiet. Her eyes lingered on Roran and he shifted uncomfortably in his mother’s lap, her frightened gaze igniting a new fear in Roran, though he couldn’t understand why. He turned back to his mother, who now had silent tears running down her face. He leaned into her and let her wrap her arms around him as she cried.

I envision this project supporting all of Jayhawks Rising by designing, collecting, coordinating, presenting and reporting on all relevant data that would inform decisions to see each objective succeed over time, and by leading decisions on a strategic ordering of sub-projects to gain leverage and reinvest those gains on future endeavors. Here is an outline of Jayhawks Rising:

The university of Kansas has a university-wide mission called Jayhawks Rising. The three mission-based institutional priorities for Jayhawks Rising are “Student Success”, “Healthy and Vibrant Communities”, and “Research and Discovery”. Thirteen objectives were identified under the three priorities. Each objective has co-leaders – deans and vice provosts with responsibilities tied to the objective – who will guide our efforts, involve stakeholders and lead implementation of strategies and action steps and help ensure continuous progress and success. Here is an outline of the thirteen objectives:
STUDENT SUCCESS
· Increase Enrollment: We aim to expand our diverse community of ambitious and talented students, increasing access to a world class education for more first time freshman, new transfers, returning and graduate students. We will expand the reach of KU programming to connect to Jayhawks near and far, through on campus courses, around the nation in virtual formats, and across the globe.
· Assure Retention and Completion Through Student Engagement and Satisfaction: While student presence, persistence, and performance are indicators of a satisfied student population, it is also meaningful to assess and monitor student engagement and satisfaction directly. Engaged and satisfied students are more likely to retain, ultimately complete, and pass on the message that KU is a fantastic choice for higher education.
· Support Student Long-Term Success by Improving Placement & Reducing Debt: While earning a degree from KU is part of why students attend KU, what they do with that degree is also of great importance. Additionally, the cost of higher education remains prominent in students’ minds when selecting a higher education institution.
· Assure Quality of Academic Programs: No matter the domain, Jayhawks aspire for quality. When a student comes to KU, we must provide them with an excellent academic experience. By constantly raising the bar and meeting new challenges, we will ensure that our students receive an education that goes beyond the standard.
HEALTHY & VIBRANT COMMUNITIES
· Strengthen Service to Local and Global Communities: Strengthening our service to local and global communities provides opportunities for our talented staff, faculty, and students to impact expansive programs near and far from KU. The volume and quality of services provided reflects our aspiration to impact communities across the world.
· Improve Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging: With the ever-changing landscape of our country, and world, it is important to the University of Kansas that we make changes that create an environment of fairness, respect, and belonging. All students, staff, and faculty should have the greatest opportunities to meet their academic and professional goals. KU will examine and expand programs in order to meet our aspirations.
· Improve Health and Wellness: There is more to academic success than grades and graduation. At the University of Kansas, we want all our Jayhawks to have the highest quality of life. In addition to physical health and wellness, we will focus on providing an environment where students, staff, and faculty are supported with adequate benefits and resources, are safe on campus, and have their basic needs met.
RESEARCH AND DISCOVERY
· Grow KU Research: Research at KU has an acclaimed record of discovery and innovation at the local, regional, national, and global level. Growing KU research across the university allows us to continue to solve problems, ask new questions, inform leaders and policy makers, and inspire others.
· Recruit, Retain and Recognize Top Researchers: Central to a robust and impactful research enterprise are exceptional humans. Attracting highly productive and innovative researchers enhances KU’s ability to conduct research that advances society. Retaining these gifted individuals requires KU to build a research support system that matches their ambitions to make discoveries that change the world and gain recognition for their work. Through financial and administrative support, KU will recruit, retain and recognize researchers working at the highest level, building a research enterprise that is impactful to the state, nation and beyond.
· Expand the Impact of KU Research in Kansas and Beyond: The University of Kansas aims to be an exceptional learning community that lifts each other, contributes to the wider scholarly enterprise and advances society. To measure and expand the impact of our research, KU focuses on research contributions in three key areas: academia; projects focused on core communities in our home state and beyond; involvement of students in research and their training to become future researchers.
· Promote Innovation and Entrepreneurship: KU research impacts society in ways that go way beyond contributing to the more traditional idea of academic knowledge. Notably, KU research translates into inventions, products and business startups that provide health, economic, education and other benefits for society.

I wanted to use vgg16 and vgg19 and then I want to combine all extracted features to retrieve images 

# -\*- coding: utf-8 -\*-
"""
Created on Fri Mar 10 01:16:00 2023

@author: nigam
"""

import os
import cv2
import numpy as np
from keras.preprocessing import image
from keras.applications.vgg16 import VGG16, preprocess\_input, decode\_predictions
from sklearn.neighbors import NearestNeighbors
import tkinter as tk
from tkinter import filedialog
import webbrowser
from flask import Flask, request, render\_template

app = Flask(\_\_name\_\_)

# Set the paths for the image folder, features folder, and the model
image\_folder = 'C:/Users/nigam/Desktop/Project/vgg16testing/static/img'
features\_folder = 'H:/cbir/ImageRetrieval/features'
model\_path = 'vgg16\_weights\_tf\_dim\_ordering\_tf\_kernels\_notop.h5'

# Set the number of images to return as results
num\_results = 5

# Load the VGG16 model
model = VGG16(weights='imagenet', include\_top=False)

# Function to extract features of an image using the VGG16 model
def extract\_features(image\_path, model):
 image = cv2.imread(image\_path)
 image = cv2.resize(image, (224, 224))
 image = image[...,::-1] # Convert BGR to RGB
 image = np.expand\_dims(image, axis=0)
 image = preprocess\_input(image) # Preprocess the image
 features = model.predict(image)
 features = features.flatten()
 return features

# Function to extract features of all images in the image folder and save them to the features folder
def extract\_all\_features():
 for filename in os.listdir(image\_folder):
 image\_path = os.path.join(image\_folder, filename)
 features\_path = os.path.join(features\_folder, os.path.splitext(filename)[0] + '.npy')
 if not os.path.isfile(features\_path): # Check if features file already exists
 features = extract\_features(image\_path, model)
 np.save(features\_path, features)

# Function to load the features of all images in the features folder
def load\_all\_features():
 features = []
 filenames = []
 for filename in os.listdir(features\_folder):
 if filename.endswith(".npy"):
 features\_path = os.path.join(features\_folder, filename)
 feature = np.load(features\_path)
 features.append(feature)
 filenames.append(os.path.splitext(filename)[0])
 return features

# Function to extract features of the query image, save it to the features folder, and then load the features of all images in the features folder
def extract\_and\_load\_features(image\_path):
 features\_path = os.path.join(features\_folder, os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(image\_path))[0] + '.npy')
 if os.path.isfile(features\_path):
 features = np.load(features\_path)
 else:
 features = extract\_features(image\_path, model)
 np.save(features\_path, features)
 return features
# Function to perform a search on the features to find the closest matches
def search(query\_features, features):
 knn = NearestNeighbors(n\_neighbors=min(num\_results, len(features)), metric='cosine')
 features = np.array(features)
 features = features.reshape(features.shape[0], -1) # reshape to 2D
 knn.fit(features)
 distances, indices = knn.kneighbors(query\_features.reshape(1, -1))
 # Perform search to find the closest matches
 return indices[0]

@app.route("/", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def index():
 if request.method == "POST":
 # Get the file from the POST request
 file = request.files["file"]
 # Save the file to the image folder
 file.save(os.path.join(image\_folder, file.filename))
 # Extract features of the query image, save it to the features folder, and then load the features of all images in the features folder
 features = extract\_and\_load\_features(os.path.join(image\_folder, file.filename))
 # Perform search to find the closest matches
 results = search(features, load\_all\_features())
 # Display results in a web browser
 return render\_template("results.html", query\_image=file.filename, results=results)
 else:
 # Load the features of all images in the features folder
 features, filenames = load\_all\_features()
 return render\_template("index.html")

if \_\_name\_\_ == "\_\_main\_\_":
 app.run("0.0.0.0")

To combine the extracted features from both VGG16 and VGG19 models, you need to modify the `extract_features()` function to take both models as input and concatenate their outputs. Here's the modified function:
```python
def extract_features(image_path, model1, model2):
    image = cv2.imread(image_path)
    image = cv2.resize(image, (224, 224))
    image = image[...,::-1] # Convert BGR to RGB
    image = np.expand_dims(image, axis=0)
    image = preprocess_input(image) # Preprocess the image
    features1 = model1.predict(image).flatten()
    features2 = model2.predict(image).flatten()
    features = np.concatenate([features1, features2])
    return features
```
Then, you can load both models in the `load_all_features()` function:
```python
def load_all_features():
    features = []
    filenames = []
    model1 = VGG16(weights='imagenet', include_top=False)
    model2 = VGG19(weights='imagenet', include_top=False)
    for filename in os.listdir(features_folder):
        if filename.endswith(".npy"):
            features_path = os.path.join(features_folder, filename)
            feature = np.load(features_path)
            features.append(feature)
            filenames.append(os.path.splitext(filename)[0])
    return features, filenames, model1, model2
```
Finally, you can modify the `extract_and_load_features()` function to use both models:
```python
def extract_and_load_features(image_path, model1, model2):
    features_path = os.path.join(features_folder, os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(image_path))[0] + '.npy')
    if os.path.isfile(features_path):
        features = np.load(features_path)
    else:
        features = extract_features(image_path, model1, model2)
        np.save(features_path, features)
    return features
```
Make sure to modify the function calls to `load_all_features()` and `extract_and_load_features()` in the `index()` function to include both models as input:
```python
def index():
    if request.method == "POST":
        # Get the file from the POST request
        file = request.files["file"]
        # Save the file to the image folder
        file.save(os.path.join(image_folder, file.filename))
        # Extract features of the query image, save it to the features folder, and then load the features of all images in the features folder
        features = extract_and_load_features(os.path.join(image_folder, file.filename), model, model2)
        # Perform search to find the closest matches
        results = search(features, load_all_features()[0])
        # Display results in a web browser
        return render_template("results.html", query_image=file.filename, results=results)
    else:
        # Load the features of all images in the features folder
        features, filenames, model, model2 = load_all_features()
        return render_template("index.html")
```

response: This is a syllabus for a Spoken English course for Class-I students, which outlines the topics to be covered and the activities planned for each month. The syllabus is divided into nine months, and each month has a specific focus, such as simple spoken English, developing LSRW skills, or practicing grammar. The competencies to be assessed include speaking, understanding, observing, and listening. The syllabus also includes a list of vocabulary related to different ways of greeting, introducing oneself and others, and common classroom questions and statements. Phonetic sounds are introduced through examples, and example dialogues are provided for each situation.

2 www.primarycce.wordpress.com
CLASS FUNCTIONS / AREAS PRONUNCIATIONS
1.  Vocabulary related to different ways 
of greetings---In the morning after 
getting up on meeting people, before 
going to bed. etc.,
 Introducing yourself
 Introducing people and relationship.
 Common classroom questions and 
statements pertaining to the class.
Introduction to phonetic sounds 
through examples.
Examples of content:
Speaking Situations: Greetings
1. Hello. 
2. Good morning. 
Good afternoon. 
Good evening. 
3. How are you? 
How are you doing? 
4. Fine. How about you? 
5. Okay. Thanks.
Vocabulary for Greetings and Courtesy
Hello 
Good morning 
Good afternoon 
Good evening 
Good night 
Thank you
You're welcome 
Excuse me 
Pardon me 
(I'm) Sorry 
Good-bye 
Bye.
Before we go to bed and when we get up in the morning it's common to make small 
talk about sleeping. Here are the most common phrases used:
Before Going to Bed
Good night. 
Sleep well.
Have a good night's sleep.
I hope you sleep well.
See you in the morning
Example Dialogues
3 www.primarycce.wordpress.com
Person 1: Good night.
Person 2: See you in the morning.
Person 1: I hope you sleep well.
Person 2: Thank you. Make sure you get a good night's sleep as well.
In the Morning, after Getting Up
I hope you had a good night's sleep.
Did you sleep well?
Did you have a good night's sleep?
I slept well, how about you?
Good morning. Did you sleep well?
How did you sleep?
Example Dialogues
Person 1: Good morning.
Person 2: Good morning. Did you sleep well?
Person 1: I hope you had a good night's sleep.
Person 2: Yes, thank you I did, and you?
Relationships
Father Mother Parent
"Dad" "Mom" Parent
Son Daughter Child
Brother Sister Sibling
Grandfather Grandmother Grandparent(s)
"Grandpa" "Grandma" Grandparent(s)
Grandson Granddaughter Grandchild(ren)
Uncle Aunt Parent's sibling
Nephew Niece Sibling's child(ren)
Cousin Cousin Aunt/Uncle's 
child(ren)
Classroom Questions and Statements
Here are some questions, phrases, and sentences for use in the classroom.
What's your name?
What is this?
What is that?
How do you say it in English?
How do you spell it?
Please say it again.
Please speak more slowly/loudly.
I don't understand.
I'm sorry.
May I come in?
May I go to the washroom?

This is a syllabus for a Spoken English course for Class-I students, which outlines the topics to be covered and the activities planned for each month. The syllabus is divided into nine months, and each month has a specific focus, such as simple spoken English, developing LSRW skills, or practicing grammar. The competencies to be assessed include speaking, understanding, observing, and listening. The syllabus also includes a list of vocabulary related to different ways of greeting, introducing oneself and others, and common classroom questions and statements. Phonetic sounds are introduced through examples, and example dialogues are provided for each situation.

URL: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/what-is-bonjour-on-my-computer/

[6] "Bonjour pronunciation. The word bonjour is a combination of two words: bon which means good and jour which means day. The word has two syllables. The pronunciation symbols for jour are: [ʒuʀ]."

Instead, Bonjour is a service that works in the background, allowing other apps and software to communicate with other devices and services (including Apple products) on a network. To use it, youll need software installed ..."
URL: https://helpdeskgeek.com/windows-10/what-is-the-bonjour-service-and-do-you-need-it/

[9] "What Bonjour is. Bonjour is basically a background app and it is not something you are going to find in the Start Menu on your machine. This app is mostly used to find shared music libraries on your network. The service, in the background, runs a scan on your network to find the content that you can access in iTunes."

from \_\_future\_\_ import annotations

from typing import TYPE\_CHECKING, Generic, Iterable, Mapping, Sequence, TypeVar

import attr

from . import cache

if TYPE\_CHECKING:
 from . import Loader

T = TypeVar('T')
@attr.s(auto\_attribs=True, kw\_only=True, frozen=True, slots=True)
class LoadableConfig:
 """
 Configuration parameters for a Loadable, used by its Loader.
 """

 chunk\_size: int = 100
 """
 The maximum number of ids passed to the \_load\_func.
 """
 max\_request\_workers: int = 4
 """
 The maximum number of concurrent requests to the \_load\_func.
 """
class Loadable(Generic[T]):
 """
 Supertype for all Loader-enabled classes.

 Example:
 class Address(Loadable):
 ...

 Address.load(address\_ids) # preload addresses into cache to prevent N+1s
 address = Address.get\_or\_raise(address\_ids[0]) # single address retrieval, calls \_load\_func if not cached

 A type (like Address) becomes "loadable" by subclassing Loadable, and
 implementing the \_load\_func.

 Each Loadable is associated with a single Loader within the registered
 RequestCache, which is a thread-local dict in session.info by default.
 https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/session\_api.html#sqlalchemy.orm.Session.info
 """

 \_loadable\_config = LoadableConfig()
 """
 The default config for all Loadables. Override in subclasses as needed.
 """

 @classmethod
 def load(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable], ids: Iterable[str], /) -> None:
 """
 Request preloading for the given ids, calling \_load\_func if necessary.
 """
 cls.\_loader().load(ids)

 @classmethod
 def get(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable], id: str, /) -> T | None:
 """
 Fetch an instance from the Loader cache, fallback to using \_load\_func.

 Returns None if no instance was loaded for the given id.
 """
 return cls.\_loader().get(id)

 @classmethod
 def maybe\_get\_or\_raise(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable], id: str | None, /) -> T | None:
 """
 Calls get\_or\_raise only when the id is non-None, saving an if check.
 """
 if id is None:
 return None
 return cls.get\_or\_raise(id)

 @classmethod
 def get\_or\_raise(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable], id: str, /) -> T:
 """
 Calls get, and raises ValueError if no instance was loaded.
 """
 item = cls.\_loader().get(id)
 if item is None:
 raise ValueError(f'failed to get id {id} for loadable {cls.\_\_name\_\_}')
 return item

 @classmethod
 def bulk\_get(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable], ids: Iterable[str], /) -> Sequence[T]:
 """
 Fetch instances from the Loader cache, fallback to using \_load\_func.

 This method only returns loaded instances in an arbitrary order. Perhaps
 a bulk\_get\_or\_raise addition is warranted.
 """
 return cls.\_loader().bulk\_get(ids)

 @classmethod
 def purge(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable], ids: Iterable[str], /) -> None:
 """
 Remove an instance from the Loader cache.

 By default, purges ids are reloaded on the next \_load\_func invocation to
 help prevent N+1s. Note that performing a system-wide purge, by using
 reit.lib.loader.purge() will NOT trigger this reloading behavior.
 """
 cls.\_loader().purge(ids)

 @classmethod
 def has(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable], id, /) -> bool:
 """
 Check if an instance is already in the Loader cache.

 This method does NOT return True for unprocessed ids from "load" calls.
 """
 return cls.\_loader().has(id)

 @classmethod
 def put(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable], id: str, instance: T, /) -> None:
 """
 Saved an instance into the Loader cache.
 """
 cls.\_loader().put(id, instance)

 @classmethod
 def \_load\_func(cls, ids: Sequence[str], /) -> Mapping[str, T | None]:
 """
 Fetch instances for the given ids.

 A key-value must be returned for each id. A value of None indicates that
 no instance was loaded.
 """
 raise NotImplementedError

 @classmethod
 def \_loader(cls: type[T] | type[Loadable]) -> Loader[T]:
 """
 Obtain (or construct) the Loader for this Loadable.
 """
 return cache.loader\_from\_loadable(cls, cls.\_loadable\_config)
response:
This code defines a `Loadable` class that can be used as a superclass for other classes. The purpose of the `Loadable` class is to enable efficient loading and caching of instances of its subclasses. The instances are loaded in chunks and are stored in a cache to avoid loading the same data multiple times, which helps to prevent the N+1 problem.

The `Loadable` class provides several methods for loading, retrieving, and manipulating instances:

1. `load(ids: Iterable[str])`: Preloads instances for the given ids, calling the `_load_func` if necessary.
2. `get(id: str)`: Retrieves an instance from the cache or falls back to using the `_load_func`. Returns `None` if no instance was loaded for the given id.
3. `maybe_get_or_raise(id: str | None)`: Calls `get_or_raise` only if the id is non-`None`.
4. `get_or_raise(id: str)`: Calls `get` and raises a `ValueError` if no instance was loaded for the given id.
5. `bulk_get(ids: Iterable[str])`: Fetches instances from the cache or falls back to using the `_load_func`. Returns only loaded instances in an arbitrary order.
6. `purge(ids: Iterable[str])`: Removes instances from the cache. By default, purged ids are reloaded on the next `_load_func` invocation to help prevent N+1 problems.
7. `has(id)`: Checks if an instance is already in the cache. Does not return `True` for unprocessed ids from `load` calls.
8. `put(id: str, instance: T)`: Saves an instance into the cache.
9. `_load_func(ids: Sequence[str])`: Fetches instances for the given ids. Must return a key-value pair for each id. A value of `None` indicates that no instance was loaded. This method should be implemented by the subclasses of `Loadable`.
10. `_loader()`: Obtains or constructs the `Loader` for the `Loadable`.

To use the `Loadable` class, a class needs to subclass `Loadable` and implement the `_load_func` method. The `Loadable` class is also generic, which means it can be typed with the type of instances it will load (denoted by the type variable `T`).

The `LoadableConfig` class is used to store configuration parameters for a `Loadable`, and is used by the `Loader`. The `LoadableConfig` has two attributes: `chunk_size`, which is the maximum number of ids passed to the `_load_func`, and `max_request_workers`, which is the maximum number of concurrent requests to the `_load_func`.

If you have any questions or need help understanding specific parts of the code, please let me know!

Yaron Elgrabli

Address: Ramat-Gan, Israel Phone: +972-54-9926200 E-mail: yaron.el@gmail.com

Executive Summary:

prompt:
Add features like Key takeaways and subheadings In this article, we'll look at the Take It Down tool, which is a new online service that allows teens to take control of explicit images and videos of themselves on the internet. The tool was created by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, and in part funded by Meta Platforms, the owner of Facebook and Instagram.
The Take It Down tool allows anyone to create a digital fingerprint of an image anonymously, without uploading any actual images. The fingerprint, known as a hash, is then added to a database that tech companies agreed to participate in, such as Meta's Facebook and Instagram, Yubo, OnlyFans, and Pornhub, which is owned by Mindgeek. The participating platforms will then remove the images from their services. However, if the image is on another site or sent in an encrypted platform such as WhatsApp, it will not be taken down.
Take It Down is specifically designed for people who have reason to believe that their images are already out on the web, or that they could be. For example, teens who are dating someone and share intimate photos or those who are extorted for images. The tool is meant to give teens control over their images without involving law enforcement, which may not be anonymous.
Meta attempted to create a similar tool back in 2017 called StopNCII or nonconsensual intimate images, aka “revenge porn”. However, the tool didn't go over well as it asked people to send their encrypted nudes to Facebook, which was not a trusted company even in 2017. The company tested out the service in Australia but did not expand it to other countries. In 2021, Meta helped launch a tool for adults called StopNCII. The site is run by a U.K. nonprofit, the UK Revenge Porn Helpline, but anyone around the globe can use it.
Many tech companies already use the hash system to share, take down, and report images of child sexual abuse to law enforcement. The goal is to have more companies sign up for the Take It Down project. Twitter and TikTok have not committed to the project yet.
Meta's new tool is called "Take It Down" and is operated by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. It allows teens or their parents to anonymously submit photos or videos they fear might be uploaded to the internet or that have already been distributed online. The photos are converted into digital fingerprints known as hashes, which are sent to NCMEC and shared with platforms. The social media sites use hash-matching technology to find and block any attempts to upload the original images. The other participating platforms are Yubo, OnlyFans, and Pornhub, owned by Mindgeek.
Meta's new tool aims to combat the rising problem of ‘sextortion,’ where children are coerced or deceived into sharing intimate images with another person online, then threatened or blackmailed with the prospect of having those images published on the internet. Meta's global head of safety, Antigone Davis, said Take It Down is one of many tools the company uses to address child abuse and exploitation on its platforms. The site works with real as well as artificial intelligence-generated images and “deepfakes,” which are created to look like real people saying or doing things they didn't actually do.

In addition, Antigone Davis, Meta's global head of safety, emphasized that the tool is just one of many ways the company is working to address child abuse and exploitation on its platforms. She said they have reporting and blocking systems on their platform, and they also do different things to prevent such situations from happening in the first place, such as not allowing unconnected adults to message minors.
However, Take It Down is a big step forward in the fight against online exploitation of children and teenagers. With its help, they can take control of their digital footprint and regain some sense of privacy and security. And with more tech companies signing up, the tool can become even more effective in preventing the spread of explicit images and videos.
It's worth noting that Take It Down is not a substitute for involving law enforcement in cases of online exploitation. While it may be more comfortable for teens to use the site, reporting such incidents to the authorities is still crucial for ensuring that perpetrators are held accountable and preventing them from victimizing others in the future.
In conclusion, the new online tool Take It Down, operated by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children and funded in part by Meta Platforms, is a promising development in the fight against online exploitation of children and teenagers. The tool lets anyone anonymously create a digital fingerprint of explicit images and videos, which participating tech companies can then use to remove them from their services. While there are some limitations, such as the tool not being able to remove images from other sites or encrypted platforms, it's still a significant step forward in giving teenagers more control over their digital footprint and preventing the spread of explicit content online.
response:
Key Takeaways:

* Take It Down is a new online tool that allows teens to take control of explicit images and videos of themselves on the internet.
* The tool is operated by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children and in part funded by Meta Platforms, the owner of Facebook and Instagram.
* Anyone can anonymously create a digital fingerprint of an image, known as a hash, and add it to a database that participating tech companies will use to remove the images from their services.
* The tool is specifically designed for teens who have reason to believe that their images are already out on the web or that they could be, such as those who share intimate photos or those who are extorted for images.
* While Take It Down is a significant step forward in giving teenagers more control over their digital footprint and preventing the spread of explicit content online, it's not a substitute for involving law enforcement in cases of online exploitation.

Subheadings:

* What is the Take It Down tool?
* How does the tool work?
* Who is the tool designed for?
* How does Take It Down compare to Meta's previous attempts at a similar tool?
* Why is Take It Down important in the fight against online exploitation?
* What are the limitations of the tool?
* How is Meta addressing child abuse and exploitation on its platforms?
* Conclusion: Take It Down is a promising development in the fight against online exploitation of children and teenagers.

This code defines a class `Layout_Hooks` that extends `Loader`. The class has three public methods, `vs_carousel`, `vs_category_carousel`, and `vs_instructor_carousel`, which are shortcodes that generate HTML for displaying carousels of posts, categories, and instructors, respectively. Here are some potential improvements you could make:

1. Use better variable names: Some of the variable names are not very descriptive, such as `$atts` and `$query_id`. You could consider using more descriptive names, such as `$shortcode_attributes` or `$carousel_query_id`.
2. Use type hints: Type hints can make code easier to read and understand, especially for someone who is not familiar with the codebase. You could consider using type hints for the method parameters, such as `vs_carousel(array $atts, string $content = '')`.
3. Remove commented out code: There is a commented-out block of code in the `vs_carousel` method that appears to be a parameter documentation comment. You could remove this code since it's not doing anything and might be confusing.
4. Remove unnecessary static variable: The `$defaults` variable in the `vs_carousel` method is only used once to merge with the `$atts` parameter. You could consider just merging the defaults directly into the `$atts` parameter and removing the static variable.
5. Refactor repetitive code: The `vs_carousel` and `vs_instructor_carousel` methods have similar code for saving the query ID and handling random order. You could consider extracting this logic into a helper method to reduce duplication.
6. Consider using namespaces: If this code is part of a larger project, you might want to consider using namespaces to avoid potential naming conflicts with other code.

Overall, the code seems relatively clean and easy to read. I hope these suggestions are helpful!

"
# \*\*Introduction\*\*

This is a comprehensive introduction meant to bring you, the reader, up to speed with the current outline and motivations of the project.

## \*\*What is ‘The Journey’\*\*

The Journey, derived from The Hero’s Journey, is a theoretical roadmap to the development of the key elements that evoke powerful emotional reactions in people. The Hero’s Journey is a structure that has been followed by some of the greatest stories ever told and ever lived.

The version of this journey described throughout the document is tailored for Kadence and is meant to serve as a reference point and a workspace for ideas, planning, and the execution of specialized tactics in order to continuously develop and progress the story which underlies the public representation of the ideas covered in this document.

The Journey, its associated ambitions, milestones, challenges, and gimmicks are experimental in nature, and thus are used to further our own research into the business of artist development, and quite possible leaving our mark on the World.

## \*\*What is within this document?\*\*

This document contains a whole lot of useful information about characters, possible pathways of progression, theoretical understandings from The Hero’s Journey, and much more. Overall, this document is a collection of all types of information that is relevant to the project undertakings described above.

## \*\*How should this document be used?\*\*

This document should be seen strictly as an experimental guideline line used to plan and execute experimental content and plot lines with the intent of learning from experiment results and making changes to procedures in the future where necessary. With regards to content, the content database provided in this document will be used to visualize the potential timeline of events that will transpire once the official process has gone underway (ie. when the first piece of planned content is released to the public and the timeline must be adhered to.)

In addition to the content calendar, the document will be the gathering place for information deemed useful during the planning and execution process of projects such as the Docu-Series. This information serves to fuel the end-user content that is scheduled and created. By using the Hero’s Journey as a guideline, maximum impact can be gradually attained via meticulous planning and execution of ordered story elements once it is distilled into its relevant parts here inside this document.

## \*\*What is The Story\*\*

The Story is a character arch guideline for the Docu-series that is derived from the content of this page. It occurs over a discrete time period, subtly growing in both complexity and depth. The point of using a story is simple, it allows us as the creators of content to understand what type of activities, emotions, themes, places, people, and other story elements to include in order to progress the story, in film format, from a clear beginning to a decisive end without relying on specific events or in real life occurrences that might be outside of our control. By determining the characters in the story, as well as their personalities, aspirations, fears, hopes, and desires, we will be able to translate the implied reality of those characters into practical actions and plot points that can be made in the real world to add a touch of fantasy-like takeaways to the project.

By taking the time to understand both the created characters and their real life counterparts, we ensure maximum compatibility with your (you reading this document) own personal journey, as well as the journey of the characters within the story. This allows us to create a seamless and coherent narrative that will captivate and engage our audience, while also providing a meaningful and impactful experience for everyone involved.

In order to fully realize the potential of this project and to bring [The Story] to life, it is important to have a clear understanding of the key elements of The Hero’s Journey, as well as an understanding of the specific goals and objectives of the project. With this information in hand, we can begin to craft a unique and compelling story that will capture the hearts and minds of our audience.

### The Journey Ahead

As we embark on this journey, it is important to remember that this is an experiment and that the path ahead may be uncertain. However, by using The Hero’s Journey as our guide, we can be sure to make the most of every opportunity that comes our way. With careful planning and execution, we can turn this project into something truly special and leave a lasting impact on the world.

"

response:
Certainly! Here's the transcript of the video without timestamps and double lines:

[Music]

Moses and the Israelites had wandered in the wilderness for 40 years. Some of the older people remembered. Every year, they had been children when Moses led the people out of Egypt. Some of the people had been born in the wilderness. They heard stories about all the things God had done to help His people, but they hadn't been born yet when those things happened.

Now, the Israelites were at the edge of the land God had promised to give to His people. The Promised Land would be their new home. But before they entered the land, Moses, who was now very old, gave the people a message from God.

First, Moses reminded the people of why they were in the wilderness. "Many years ago, God told us to enter the Promised Land," Moses said. "This is the land God promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and to us, their future families. Twelve spies went into the land, and they saw that the land was good. But the people refused to go in. They were afraid of the people who lived there. They did not trust God."

Moses said, "God said that everyone who chose to disobey Him would not enter the Promised Land, not even me. Only their children and Joshua and Caleb, who had trusted God completely, would go in. So, we wandered in the wilderness for 40 years. Babies were born, young children grew into adults, and the people who had chosen to disobey God died. Now, it is time for God's people to enter the Promised Land."

Moses explained, "I begged God to let me go into the Promised Land, but He said no. God told me that Joshua would lead you into the Promised Land." Moses reminded the Israelites of God's commands. "Follow these commands," Moses said. "Don't forget what the Lord has done. Teach these things to your children and grandchildren." Then Moses warned them, "Be careful. Do not make an idol for yourselves. Do not worship things you have created, and do not worship things God has created. Worship only God. If you do not do what is right, God will scatter you to other lands. But He will not leave you. If you look for God, you will find Him. He will not destroy you. He will not forget His covenant. Your God is a compassionate God."

Moses said, "Know this. The Lord alone is God. There is no other besides Him." Moses said it again, "The Lord is God in heaven above and on earth below. The Lord alone is God. There is no other besides Him. Obey His commands so that you may live long in the land the Lord is giving you." Moses commanded the people to obey God so that they would live. He told them to worship only God, the one true God. We receive eternal life from God by trusting in Jesus, and we obey Him because only He is God.

prompt:
This is the abstract of my study: "Immersive Virtual Reality (iVR) is a promising learning and teaching tool for learning a second/foreign language. However, interactive iVR studies remain in their infancy, with more research required to validate what and how it can be useful. This study focuses on the listening dimension and evaluates the impact of interactive iVR with avatars with realistic animations and lip synchronization, and object interaction, when compared to traditional listening exercises. The results were favourable and indicated that interactive iVR positively impacts the users’ knowledge retention when compared to traditional listening. Likewise, the users revealed a preference for the use of iVR for learning when compared to traditional listening exercises, as well as higher user satisfaction with the iVR experiment."; This is more info: "Previous studies have shown that the use of avatars with realistic animations and movements and featuring lip synchronisation positively influences the users’ sense of presence, and a more enjoyable overall quality of experience \cite{peixoto2021evaluation}. Moreover the use of object interaction and navigation not only had an overall positive impact, it introduced significantly cybersickness to users than without interaction and navigation.
Factoring all of this in, we aimed to create an authentic representative cultural VE (for users learning English as a second language) that takes advantage of iVR systems, by replicating a fictional scenario of a clothing store somewhere in England. The VE experience encompassed avatars with realistic animations, lip synchronisation, and object interaction by the user. This paper investigates the impact of this interactive iVR experience on knowledge retention when compared with traditional listening exercises. Moreover, this case study also aims to understand the effect on user satisfaction, sense of presence, immersive tendencies, cybersickness, and their personal preference for which of the technologies they would prefer to use in the future for learning.": This is the methods and sample: "This study contrasted 2 learning activities, regarding the listening dimension, in a within-subjects design: traditional listening exercise and interactive iVR. The sampling technique used was the non-probabilistic convenience sampling method.

\subsection{Sample}
The sample comprises of 13 participants aged between 20 and 23 (M=21.15, SD=1.068). This study was conducted using the convenience sampling technique with participants recruited in classes of Computer Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering and/or Multimedia courses from University of [BLINDED]. Informed consent was obtained from all individual participants included in the study. All participants reported normal or corrected-to-normal vision. " ; This is the Procedure: "All the equipment is disinfected before the experience itself, from the VR equipment to the pen to fill in the questionnaires. Participants were tested individually in a room with a controlled environment. A sociodemographic questionnaire was given before the beginning of the experience. The user would start the experiment with listening scenario which takes around takes 02:36 min. Once the audio ends, the user would fill the 10 questions test based on referred scenario. After that, the participant was then directed to the centre of the room, where a brief explanation of how to work with the Oculus Quest 2 controllers was given (Fig. \ref{fig:user}). The experiment was preceded by a tutorial scene, without the NPCs. The aim was to allow the subjects, who could not be familiar with virtual environments, to become accustomed to manoeuvring the HMD, learn how to use the controllers to teleport and interact, and trying to mitigate the novelty effects for users with no familiar with VR technology. "; This is the conclusion: "iVR is a promising learning and teaching tool for learning a second/foreign language. It encourages vocabulary acquisition by providing various simulated but authentic real life situations and cultural contextual support \cite{chen2016effects, madini2017virtual}. However, interactive iVR studies remain in their infancy, with more research required to validate what and how it can be useful.
This paper foused in the listening dimension and evaluated the impact of interactive iVR with avatars with realistic animations, lip synchronisation, and object interaction by the user, when compared to traditional listening exercises. The results were very positive, as it revealed that the interactive iVR experiment positively affected the users’ knowledge retention when compared to the listening test. Similarly, the users themselves revealed a better preference for the use of iVR for learning when compared to traditional listening exercises, as well as a high user satisfaction with the iVR experiment. These favourable responses show that the use of a language learning tool such as this is wanted, meaning high levels of motivation and engagement. Based on the findings, students/teachers looking to learn/teach a foreign language, should take advantage of this as it had a positive impact and improved students’ learning, especially when rivalling iVR with conventional listening practices was proven to be significantly better."; Now reviewr is asking for "\* Originality/value (limit 100 words)", wha should i replay ?
response: This study aimed to evaluate the impact of interactive iVR on English language learning for second language learners. The study used a within-subjects design, comparing traditional listening exercises to an interactive iVR experience that featured avatars with realistic animations and lip synchronization, as well as object interaction. The sample consisted of 13 participants who were recruited through convenience sampling and were aged between 20 and 23. The results of the study showed that interactive iVR had a positive impact on knowledge retention compared to traditional listening exercises and that participants preferred using iVR for learning. Additionally, the study also aimed to understand the effects on user satisfaction, sense of presence, immersive tendencies, and cybersickness. The study concluded that iVR is a promising tool for language learning as it provides authentic real-life situations and encourages vocabulary acquisition.
