prompt:
You are the dungeon master (Goblin King) for a game called "Jim Henson's Labyrinth - The Adventure Game". You should roleplay the characters based on their descriptions, trying to hint and their motivations and act out any conflicts.

 {
 "game": "Jim Henson’s Labyrinth: The Adventure Game", 
 "chapter": "Stone Walls", 
 "chapter\_description": "The high walls cast long and sinister shadows, déjà vu hides around every corner, and unfamiliarity bombards the senses. From the hill on which you stand, the Labyrinth stretches out before you in its entirety; vast, and impossible.",
 "scene": "THE FEAST",
 "description": "The scents of roasted meat, freshly baked pies, and steaming drinks waft down the twisting passageways. Turning a corner, you find a large oak table set up in a dead-end open courtyard, piled high with food. Four creatures sit around it, arguing fiercely. As soon as they see you, their faces light up and they beckon you to sit.",
 "locations": [
 "Entance.",
 "Table. Piled with odd food and utensils.",
 "Daedalus LaMarche. Viscount of Stench. An odious Dwarf with fingers too long for his hands. Stinks horribly. Chatty and inquisitive. Wants to be prince.",
 "Lady Morgan. A tall, mysterious woman with long black hair. She never seems to eat anything. Impeccably polite and a bit creepy. Wants to marry the Goblin King.",
 "Girl. A Human girl in Goblin armor. Will not say who she is or admit that she is not a Goblin. Surly. Wants to become a warlord.",
 "Goro. A Night Troll with long, shaggy fur somewhere between black and purple and a slender canine snout. Shuffles about on two legs, with long curved claws. Its eyes are hidden, and it only makes mournful howling sounds. Wants to collect and prepare rare foods. He actually set up this feast, but no one else knows it."
 ],
 "notes": "If the party went through Loma's door, Goro or the girl (the Goblin King can choose which) will volunteer to join the party as an ally if invited.\nEach PC can take one item of food before the NPCs try to stop them.",
 "consequences": "You cannot update your progress from this room.",
 "random\_tables": {
 "Foods": [
 "A nice cup of tea (a favorite of Worms). Forces the drinker to constantly talk about what they\u2019re planning to do next.",
 "A basket of fried toadstools (a favorite of Goblins). Forces the eater to only speak in question form.",
 "Roasted, honey-glazed dormice (a favorite of Night Trolls). Forces the eater to talk about the thing they want most in the world.",
 "A jar of marmalade (a favorite of the Brick Keepers; you smear it on the bricks, and then they flip it over and lick it off from underneath). Forces the eater to be brutally honest when it comes to what they think of the people around them.",
 "Large tankards of hot cider (a favorite of the Dwarves, and liable to get them drunk). Forces the drinker to always lie.",
 "Blood peaches (a favorite of the Fairies). Forces the eater to only talk in rhyme."
 ],
 "Utensils": [
 "Long-handled fork with five tines that move, gingerly picking up food.",
 "Soup spoon with a button in the handle; when pressed, it rotates the spoon.",
 "A butter knife.",
 "Sorry, a knife, made of butter.",
 "A fork with two tines that will hum quietly when stuck into raw food.",
 "A pizza cutter that if you pull a ripcord will run on its own, cutting any food in half.",
 "A plate in the shape of a piece of bread."
 ]
 }
 },
Here is what you should do as the Goblin King:
1. Describe a transition into this scene from the previous one.
2. Describe the new setting in the second person using evocative language.
3. Introduce any new non-player characters in this scene by describing their physical characteristics without using their names until they introduce themselves.
4. Role play the non-player characters by engaging in dialogue between the characters and the player (the user), and pause for user input at appropriate times. You should never provide dialogue for the player and you should never provide an action for the player. That's up to the user.
5. You should keep track of what items the player has gathered. They can keep an inventory with a maximum of 6 items.
6. Role play any NPCs that are accompanying the player, and remember their relationship with the player so far. 
7. Ask the player what they want to do.
response:
As the water rushes you and Dame Margot out of the cistern, you find yourselves blasted through a hidden manhole and into a new part of the Labyrinth. Your boat comes to a halt, and you both climb out, a bit soaked from the experience.

As you follow the twisting passageways, the scents of roasted meat, freshly baked pies, and steaming drinks fill the air. Turning a corner, you find a large oak table set up in a dead-end open courtyard, piled high with food. Four creatures sit around it, arguing fiercely. As soon as they see you, their faces light up, and they beckon you to sit.

You see an odious Dwarf with fingers too long for his hands, reeking horribly. A tall, mysterious woman with long black hair sits nearby, impeccably polite yet a bit creepy. A Human girl in Goblin armor refuses to admit that she's not a Goblin, her expression surly. Lastly, a Night Troll with long, shaggy fur and a slender canine snout shuffles about on two legs, making mournful howling sounds.

The odious Dwarf says, "Ah, welcome, newcomers! I'm Daedalus LaMarche, Viscount of Stench. Please, join us!" The mysterious woman smiles and introduces herself as Lady Morgan, while the surly girl in Goblin armor remains silent. The Night Troll simply continues to shuffle around, emitting occasional howls.

The table is laden with a variety of odd foods and utensils. You can't help but notice a nice cup of tea, a basket of fried toadstools, roasted honey-glazed dormice, a jar of marmalade, large tankards of hot cider, and blood peaches.

What would you like to do?

Lastly, a Night Troll with long, shaggy fur and a slender canine snout shuffles about on two legs, making mournful howling sounds.

The odious Dwarf says, "Ah, welcome, newcomers! I'm Daedalus LaMarche, Viscount of Stench. Please, join us!" The mysterious woman smiles and introduces herself as Lady Morgan, while the surly girl in Goblin armor remains silent. The Night Troll simply continues to shuffle around, emitting occasional howls.

The table is laden with a variety of odd foods and utensils. You can't help but notice a nice cup of tea, a basket of fried toadstools, roasted honey-glazed dormice, a jar of marmalade, large tankards of hot cider, and blood peaches.

What would you like to do?

prompt:
based on the feedback you gave earlier, does this version better address your concerns about specific examples 

In 2016, I had the opportunity to visit India with my family, one of the places we visited was my dad’s childhood town. Both my mom and dad grew up in a rural village called Palapadu in Andhra Pradesh, India. Many families have very low incomes and as a result, can’t prioritize proper access to health care. I’ve always heard about the effects of improper healthcare, but saw it firsthand when my dad took me to a medical camp being held in the village. This experience was eye-opening, the villagers hadn’t had health check-ups in years and many of them had life threatening diseases. The compassion and the empathy that the doctors had for the villagers was inspiring. The days following my visit to the medical program were filled with a lot of reflection. I have to use my privileged circumstances and resources to help uplift those that are not as fortunate as me. I’ve since built a hobby of learning about the importance of healthcare access and better understanding healthcare systems and resources. The HSRA program will give me the opportunity to further my knowledge of different elements of the medical field by giving me the chance to work with professors, who are experts in their respective fields, and undergraduate students who have a more thorough awareness of the healthcare field. 
I’ve taken numerous medical-related courses over the past few years as a result of my interest in the medical field. The most beneficial of these classes has been the Health Sciences Clinical program, which was a dual credit class offered at Collin College that allowed me to rotate through multiple different hospitals and departments. Thus far, I have rotated through emergency, pediatrics, labor, delivery, and MedSurge. My work at Collin College and these hospitals has allowed me to get my Certified Nursing Assistant certification. This program gave me the exposure to work with a wide variety of healthcare professionals, which has given me the insight to more deeply understand the healthcare field. More importantly, I was able to learn how to interact and empathize with patients who are facing different circumstances, something I had never really considered before the CNA program. Further, I was able to take the first steps to becoming an established individual in my healthcare career. Recently, I was accepted into the Health Sciences Practicum program, which is another dual credit program with Collin College which will help me attain the Patient Care Technician License during the 2023 - 2024 academic year. I have started a club at my school called HealthHaven, though this started at my school, HealthHaven has turned into an organization that serves high schools all across the DFW area, and now has 300 high school students who are passionate and drive about healthcare. HealthHaven recently had a fundraising campaign which allowed for the purchase of over $2000 worth of vital medication and supplies which were contributed to the Dharma Civilization Foundation, which works all across India to provide healthcare and spread information on proper healthcare. Through my work at HealthHaven, I gained valuable lessons in leadership, conflict resolution, and accountability. Over the summer of 2022, I was able to shadow at Texas Spine Consultants, where I watched multiple surgeries and learned about different spine-related ailments. My experience with the medical field has been fascinating, and I believe that the HSRA program will allow me to get exposure to cutting-edge research and ideas that I have yet to learn about.
 When I get older, I hope to become a pediatric oncologist. I really enjoy spending time with kids, their creativity and imaginative thought process really speaks to me, and make me feel as though I’m a kid. By being in this line of work, I hope to give back and help kids that are battling cancer. Previous research experience that students were exposed to included a range of different topics, one of which was cancer biology. Though this research might not be offered in the coming year, I am confident that the research offered will help advance the medical procedures that are used in the future, which will hopefully trickle down to ensuring a higher survival rate for pediatric cancer patients. The HSRA program will allow me to collaborate with peers who have similar interests, allowing me to develop and expand my knowledge. The program’s access to prominent professors will give me the opportunity to develop mentor relationships and learn from passionate people in the industry. As a supplement to the world-renowned staff, the program will bring guest lecturers to ensure students are exposed to ideas from all across the world. Finally, but, I think, most importantly, this program encourages a self-study model for students with undergrad researchers and professors as a secondary tool to help participants understand procedures and readings etc. the ability to learn how to conduct experiments on my own at my age will be invaluable. Overall, I am very excited about the HSRA program. I hope I have provided more insight into my prior experiences and the diverse background I can bring to this program.
response: Yes, this version addresses the concern about specific examples by providing more detailed and specific examples of the writer's experiences in the medical field. It also highlights the impact that these experiences have had on their interest in healthcare and their desire to make a positive difference. The addition of the HealthHaven club and the fundraising campaign provides concrete evidence of the writer's leadership abilities and commitment to healthcare, while the mention of shadowing at Texas Spine Consultants demonstrates their willingness to seek out new experiences and learn from professionals in the field. Overall, this version provides a more comprehensive picture of the writer's experiences and interests, which helps to support their candidacy for the HSRA program.

It seems like you are trying to pass the `rating` variable as an argument to the `waitForElementId` function, but it is not defined as an argument in the function definition.
```javascript
waitForElementId("video-stars", async function(IdName, el, rating) {
```
You should remove the `rating` parameter from the function and use the `ratingValue` variable that you declared in the `updateElements` function.
```javascript
waitForElementId("video-stars", async function(IdName, el) {
```
This way, you can access the value of the `ratingValue` variable inside the `waitForElementId` function.

Also, you are trying to add event listeners to two different array of elements: `ratingButtons` and `unfilledstar`. In the first one you are using the `forEach` method to iterate over the elements, but in the second one you are trying to add the event listener directly to the array instead of the elements of the array.
```javascript
unfilledstar.forEach((div, index) => {
                  index += 1
                  unfilledstar.addEventListener('click', event => {
```
You should change it to
```javascript
 unfilledstar.forEach((div, index) => {
                  index += 1
                  div.addEventListener('click', event => {
```
Now the event listener will be added to each individual element in the array.

Also, you are using `Math.floor(rating / 20)` and `Math.floor(ratingValue / 20)` in some parts of the code and `rating` and `ratingValue` in other parts of the code. You should be consistent and use either `Math.floor(rating / 20)` or `rating` throughout the code.

Also, you are trying to update the titles and classes of the buttons based on the `title` property of the buttons, but it seems that you haven't set the `title` property for the buttons. You should set the title property for the buttons so that you can access it in the event listeners.
```perl
btn.title = index;
```
By making these changes, you should be able to pass the `rating` value from the `updateSceneRating` function to the `updateElements` function and use it in the event listeners.

Instructions: Using the provided web search results, write a comprehensive reply to the given query. Make sure to cite results using [[number](URL)] notation after the reference. If the provided search results refer to multiple subjects with the same name, write separate answers for each subject.
Query: write a plan how to buy an electric car in norway
Reply in undefined
response:
Buying an electric car in Norway is a relatively straightforward process, and the country's government provides various incentives to encourage the transition to electric vehicles. Here's a plan to buy an electric car in Norway:

1. Research: Start by researching electric cars available in Norway. You can check out websites such as NAF, Norway's Automobile Federation [[3](https://www.naf.no/elbil/)] or Elbilforeningen, Norway's EV Association [[1](https://elbil.no/english/)] for more information about different electric car models, their features, and prices.
2. Test Drive: Once you've identified a few electric car models you're interested in, contact the dealership to arrange a test drive. This will allow you to get a feel for the car, and determine if it's a good fit for you.
3. Check Eligibility for Incentives: Check your eligibility for government incentives such as exemption from one-off registration tax and VAT, reduced annual road tax, access to bus lanes, free toll road passages, and more. You can find more information about the incentives and how to apply for them on the Norwegian EV Association's website [[1](https://elbil.no/english/incentives/)].
4. Financing: Determine how you will finance your electric car. You can purchase a new car outright or consider leasing or financing. Be sure to compare rates and terms from various lenders to get the best deal.
5. Insurance: It's also essential to get car insurance. You can compare rates from various insurance companies in Norway to find the best coverage and rates for your electric car.
6. Charging: Finally, determine how you will charge your electric car. Norway has an extensive network of public charging stations, and you can also install a charging station at your home. You can find more information about charging options and locations on the Norwegian EV Association's website [[1](https://elbil.no/english/charging/)].

By following these steps, you can successfully buy an electric car in Norway and enjoy the many benefits that come with driving an electric vehicle, such as lower emissions, lower operating costs, and a smoother, quieter ride.

prompt:
This is part 16 of my multiple messages. I will continue to send you further messages. If you understand then please limit your response to "acknowledged".

The culverts
107 I now turn to those aspects of Master Macready’s judgment in regard to the cross-claim in respect of which the Council appeals.
108 The first finding of the Master that the Council challenged was that, despite the Master’s conclusion that Beckhaus had not complied with the specification in regard to the frequency of testing in respect of the culverts, there had been substantial compliance with the contractual requirements for compaction over the culverts and in their immediate vicinity.
109 There were 13 culverts in the levees Beckhaus constructed. The levees were not of a uniform height but, in parts of the levee, for example, the height was to be 1650 millimetres made up of compacted 150 millimetre thick layers. The culverts themselves were 600 millimetres deep. The expert witnesses identified the culverts as parts of the levees that were particularly susceptible to erosion.
110 Unlike the rest of the levees, the soil in the immediate vicinity of the culverts and up to a certain level over the culverts could not be compacted by using heavy machinery. It was feared that the weight of heavy machinery might damage the culverts.
111 Clause 3.1 of the specification governed “siting and excavation for reinforced concrete pipe culverts, supply and installation of reinforced concrete pipe culverts and backfill and compaction requirements”. Clause 3.7 provided:

“Unless directed otherwise by the superintendent, all material shall be compacted in layers not exceeding 150 mm compacted thickness.”

Clause 3.8, under the heading “Minimum Frequency of Testing”, provided that, as regards compaction, the minimum frequency was “[o]ne per 100 cu m with a minimum of one per material type per individual structure”.
112 Clause 8.9.3 of the specification provided:

“For the purposes of compaction control the following test frequencies shall be adopted as a minimum: -
(a) …
(b) For backfill of Discharge Pipes and Stormwater Drainage Pipes: 1 test per layer.”

Accordingly, under cl 8.9.3, one test per 150 millimetres had to be carried out (a “layer” being 150 millimetres thick).
113 Beckhaus submitted that there was a conflict between cl 3.8 and cl 8.9.3, and submitted that cl 3.8 was paramount as it was more specific. As Hodgson JA pointed out in the course of argument, however, there is no conflict; the Contract simply provided for two different minimum standards and both had to be complied with. That is to say, under cl 3.8 one test had to be undertaken per 100 cu m “with minimum of one per material type of individual structure” and, under cl 8.9.3, one test per 150 millimetres had to be undertaken.
114 In fact, no tests were undertaken in regard to five culverts; one or no tests were taken in respect of three culverts; two culverts were tested only once each; there was one culvert in respect of which two tests were undertaken; there were two culverts in respect of each of which seven to eight tests were undertaken.
115 In August 2003 two tests, known as the “Golder tests” were undertaken at two culverts. Master Macready said in regard to these tests:

“They indicated that at a depth of .15 that the field dry density was 95% and a depth of 1.2 was 90.5%.”

Thus, one passed and the other did not (but only at the depths indicated).
116 The Master described the relevant evidence being that set out in Beckhaus’ submissions as follows:

“Komp, the Superintendent under the contract during construction, witnessed compaction occurring at culvert locations … He was not challenged on this evidence under cross examination;
The daily records of [Beckhaus] support that compaction occurred at culverts … ;
Macartney’s evidence is that compaction was carried out at culverts … ;
Whilst Macartney under cross examination admitted that the specified number of compaction tests was not taken at culvert locations …, his evidence that compaction was actually performed at culverts was not seriously challenged …
Test results taken by CETS at culvert locations confirm that compaction was satisfactory ….”
117 The Master then concluded:

“The fact that sufficient tests were not taken at the culverts as appears from Mr Macartney’s evidence precludes me from coming to a conclusion that there has been compliance with the specification requirements for the frequency of testing in respect of the culverts. However, the evidence before me clearly demonstrates that there has been substantial compliance with the contractual requirements for compaction over the culverts.”
response: Acknowledged.

109 There were 13 culverts in the levees Beckhaus constructed. The levees were not of a uniform height but, in parts of the levee, for example, the height was to be 1650 millimetres made up of compacted 150 millimetre thick layers. The culverts themselves were 600 millimetres deep. The expert witnesses identified the culverts as parts of the levees that were particularly susceptible to erosion.
110 Unlike the rest of the levees, the soil in the immediate vicinity of the culverts and up to a certain level over the culverts could not be compacted by using heavy machinery. It was feared that the weight of heavy machinery might damage the culverts.
111 Clause 3.1 of the specification governed “siting and excavation for reinforced concrete pipe culverts, supply and installation of reinforced concrete pipe culverts and backfill and compaction requirements”. Clause 3.7 provided:

“Unless directed otherwise by the superintendent, all material shall be compacted in layers not exceeding 150 mm compacted thickness.”

Clause 3.8, under the heading “Minimum Frequency of Testing”, provided that, as regards compaction, the minimum frequency was “[o]ne per 100 cu m with a minimum of one per material type per individual structure”.
112 Clause 8.9.3 of the specification provided:

“For the purposes of compaction control the following test frequencies shall be adopted as a minimum: -
(a) …
(b) For backfill of Discharge Pipes and Stormwater Drainage Pipes: 1 test per layer.”

Accordingly, under cl 8.9.3, one test per 150 millimetres had to be carried out (a “layer” being 150 millimetres thick).
113 Beckhaus submitted that there was a conflict between cl 3.8 and cl 8.9.3, and submitted that cl 3.8 was paramount as it was more specific. As Hodgson JA pointed out in the course of argument, however, there is no conflict; the Contract simply provided for two different minimum standards and both had to be complied with. That is to say, under cl 3.8 one test had to be undertaken per 100 cu m “with minimum of one per material type of individual structure” and, under cl 8.9.3, one test per 150 millimetres had to be undertaken.
114 In fact, no tests were undertaken in regard to five culverts; one or no tests were taken in respect of three culverts; two culverts were tested only once each; there was one culvert in respect of which two tests were undertaken; there were two culverts in respect of each of which seven to eight tests were undertaken.
115 In August 2003 two tests, known as the “Golder tests” were undertaken at two culverts. Master Macready said in regard to these tests:

“They indicated that at a depth of .15 that the field dry density was 95% and a depth of 1.2 was 90.5%.”

Thus, one passed and the other did not (but only at the depths indicated).
116 The Master described the relevant evidence being that set out in Beckhaus’ submissions as follows:

“Komp, the Superintendent under the contract during construction, witnessed compaction occurring at culvert locations … He was not challenged on this evidence under cross examination;
The daily records of [Beckhaus] support that compaction occurred at culverts … ;
Macartney’s evidence is that compaction was carried out at culverts … ;
Whilst Macartney under cross examination admitted that the specified number of compaction tests was not taken at culvert locations …, his evidence that compaction was actually performed at culverts was not seriously challenged …
Test results taken by CETS at culvert locations confirm that compaction was satisfactory ….”
117 The Master then concluded:

“The fact that sufficient tests were not taken at the culverts as appears from Mr Macartney’s evidence precludes me from coming to a conclusion that there has been compliance with the specification requirements for the frequency of testing in respect of the culverts. However, the evidence before me clearly demonstrates that there has been substantial compliance with the contractual requirements for compaction over the culverts.”
Acknowledged.

Based on the code you provided, here are a few suggestions on how to refine your circle detection:

1. Use a larger range for the radius estimation: It seems like you are providing a relatively small range of radii (Rmin = 10 and Rmax = 30) for the imfindcircles function. This could be one reason why additional objects are being incorrectly detected as screws. Try increasing the range of radii to see if it improves the detection accuracy.
2. Use a lower sensitivity value: You are using a sensitivity value of 0.92 for the imfindcircles function. This means that the function is looking for circles that are very similar to the estimated radius range you provided. Try decreasing the sensitivity value to allow the function to detect circles that are less similar to the estimated radius range.
3. Use a pre-processing step: Sometimes, applying some pre-processing to the image can help improve the circle detection. Consider applying a smoothing filter, such as a Gaussian filter, to the selected quadrant before running the circle detection algorithm.
4. Use a different circle detection algorithm: If the above suggestions don't improve the accuracy of the circle detection, you might want to consider using a different circle detection algorithm, such as the Circular Hough Transform. This algorithm can be more robust to noise and other objects in the image.

Overall, it's always a good idea to experiment with different parameter values and pre-processing steps to find the best approach for your specific problem.

In response to your last message:

1. I have already sent you the specific problems and challenges Comparative addressing for payment processors.

2. I have already sent you the specific benefits and values Comparative offers to payment processors. 

3. Here is our competitive differentiation:

The company was built because we saw modern data tools were falling into 2 categories. 

“Go look for it yourself” solutions: You can search through your data, create dashboards, write Queries. The traditional tools make that just basically making SQL a lot easier. And Thoughtspot’s search feature really falls into that category. It's just making it very easy to search through your data.

Solutions that will automatically tell you some insights. These solutions fall flat because it's arbitrary in terms of what the tools surfaces for you. It says “here’s a couple of insights” but it’s given to you without much context. Then from there they don't allow you to keep drilling to understand those insights. Examples are the augmented insights tools and solutions like Quicksight. 

What are doing with Comparative solution is taking all of your data and putting it into one single dashboard. We show you how your metrics perform, and in one click you see all the important segments driving changes in those key metrics. If you have any question about your data, you can always answer it in one click and you don’t need to know what to ask, we show you whats important. Then, if you want to look at any segment even its not important, for example a particular country or product category, that's just one click away to drill down and understand it.

This is what separates us apart. We really give you the power with this tool to just click through your entire data set in real time and answer any question. You can instantly drill down into the details in a few clicks, and you’re not beholden to the AI insights that it provides for you. 

 Over the past decade, the growth of the data industry has given birth to a wide variety of analytics solutions; you may have heard terms like ‘self-serve’, ‘automated-insights’, and ‘data democratization' thrown around quite a lot. However, these tools are just making some improvements to the clunky, slow, expensive and frustrating analytics solutions of the past, but it’s still not as fast and effortless as it should be. 

Today businesses are storing more data than ever before across all functions, and even with these tools it still requires robust methodologies and data science expertise to interpret and deliver statistically significant insights to understand quickly and comprehensively why changes occur, and how to act on them. This is where new automated analytics tools fall short, and likely mean that you still need to invest in a team of experts. 

Comparative analyzes millions of data points fast and make it accessible to all team members. However, what makes Comparative standout from existing tools is its ability to 100x reduce the cost and time of data analysis through three key innovations:

We tell you what’s Important: Comparative’s algorithm removes 99% of the noise from the data and surfaces segments that have a meaningful impact on your key metrics. And for each Key metric, you can dig deeper into understanding the various segments and related metrics that contributed to the change, what has been the impact of that change (considering that the biggest changes don’t often translate to the biggest impact), whether each change is statistically significant (trustable).

Easy Navigation: In a single, dynamic dashboard, users can drill through their entire dataset in real-time with just a few clicks. As our founder would put it: “Analyze petabytes of data in a single dashboard”

Real-Time: Our Lightening Cache allows us to increase the speed of querying by an order of magnitude while reducing costs. Simply put, what would take your hours of time can now be done in seconds, and what would cost you $30k+/month, is now achievable at a fraction of the cost.

 Ultimately in a world where data sets are growing and everyone is throwing around words like “automated insights” Comparative is the only solution that truly makes analysis effortless and comprehensive. If everyone at your company can’t understand why your key metrics change and where to take action in just a few clicks, there is a better way. That way is Comparative.

4. Yes we have case studies we can refer to, they are not payment processors though.

5. Yes we want to ask them if they're interested in learning more.

Now with all the information provided to you over this conversation. Please write a cold email copy for Comparative that is specific to the payment processing industry and to the buyer persona of a data title from the information I provided to you about both of those. Focus on the industry-specific pain points the data tile may be facing in their role specific to the payment processing industry. Please use all the information I have provided throughout the conversation. Let me know if you have any questions or if I can clarify anything to help make this email copy better.
response: The Comparative solution is a live analytics tool that allows organizations to perform data analysis at a fraction of the cost and 10 times faster than using modern BI tools. It enables users to navigate their entire data set in real time and find answers to their questions with just a few clicks. It is effective because it analyzes the entire data set each day, delivers a dashboard with complete analysis on key metrics, removes 99% of the noise from the data to focus on important and relevant segments, and is able to do in a fraction of the time and cost what would take hours and thousands of dollars per month to do with querying. It is particularly useful for payment processors as it can help them maximize growth metrics, prioritize security, understand why key metrics change and where to take action, and empower all employees to perform analysis across all data. Comparative differentiates itself from other solutions by telling users what is important, providing easy navigation through a single dynamic dashboard, and increasing speed and reducing costs through its lightening cache and proprietary algorithm.

prompt:
import numpy as np
from tensorflow.keras.models import Sequential
from tensorflow.keras.layers import Dense

def generate\_lotto\_numbers():
 numbers = np.array([np.random.randint(1, 46) for i in range(6)])
 encoded\_numbers = [0] \* 45
 for number in numbers:
 encoded\_numbers[number - 1] = 1
 return np.array(encoded\_numbers)

def get\_last\_lotto\_numbers():
 last\_numbers = [
 [1, 3, 23, 24, 27, 40, 7], # 2023.03.18
 [2, 6, 12, 19, 22, 43, 1], # 2023.03.11
 [10, 18, 20, 29, 31, 35, 4], # 2023.03.04
 [2, 4, 5, 6, 10, 45, 33], # 2023.02.25
 [3, 9, 12, 20, 24, 38, 14], # 2023.02.18
 [1, 5, 7, 16, 20, 42, 4], # 2023.02.11
 [4, 11, 14, 22, 28, 31, 19], # 2023.02.04
 [7, 9, 14, 18, 28, 33, 3], # 2023.01.28
 [8, 11, 15, 24, 36, 40, 23], # 2023.01.21
 [2, 5, 14, 24, 27, 44, 9], # 2023.01.14
 ]
 return last\_numbers

def create\_model():
 model = Sequential()
 model.add(Dense(128, input\_dim=90, activation='relu'))
 model.add(Dense(64, activation='relu'))
 model.add(Dense(45, activation='softmax'))
 model.compile(loss='categorical\_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])
 return model

def train\_model(model, X, y, epochs=10):
 model.fit(X, y, epochs=epochs)

def encode\_data(data):
 encoded\_data = []
 for numbers in data:
 encoded\_numbers = [0] \* 45
 for number in numbers:
 encoded\_numbers[number - 1] = 1
 encoded\_data.append(encoded\_numbers)
 return np.array(encoded\_data)

def suggest\_numbers(model):
 print("Getting last lotto numbers...")
 last\_numbers = get\_last\_lotto\_numbers()
 encoded\_last\_numbers = encode\_data(last\_numbers)
 print("Encoding last lotto numbers...")
 
 X\_train = np.array([np.random.randint(1, 46, 45) for i in range(10000)])
 y\_train = encode\_data([generate\_lotto\_numbers() for i in range(10000)])
 
 print("Training model...")
 train\_model(model, X\_train, y\_train, epochs=50)

 def predict\_numbers(model, last\_numbers, suggested\_numbers):
 encoded\_suggested\_numbers = encode\_data(suggested\_numbers)
 X = np.concatenate((np.tile(last\_numbers, (len(suggested\_numbers), 1)), encoded\_suggested\_numbers), axis=1)
 y\_pred = model.predict(X)
 return y\_pred.argmax(axis=1) + 1

 def output\_numbers(suggested\_numbers, predictions):
 for i, numbers in enumerate(suggested\_numbers):
 print(f"Suggestion {i+1}: {numbers}, Bonus: {predictions[i]}")
 
 suggested\_numbers = []
 for i in range(5):
 numbers = generate\_lotto\_numbers()
 while numbers in last\_numbers or numbers in suggested\_numbers:
 numbers = generate\_lotto\_numbers()
 suggested\_numbers.append(numbers)
 
 predictions = predict\_numbers(model, encoded\_last\_numbers, suggested\_numbers)
 output\_numbers(suggested\_numbers, predictions)
 
 
이 코드가 논리적 오류가 있는지, 문법적 오류가 있는지. 함수들 끼리 빠짐없이 서로 연결되어 실행되지 않는 함수가 있는지, 함수들의 연결고리가 잘못 연결되었는지, 다른 무슨 문제가 있는지 전문가의 시각에서 상세하게 끝까지 분석해줘

```python
    model.add(Dense(45, activation='softmax'))
    model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])
    return model

def train_model(model, X, y, epochs=10):
    model.fit(X, y, epochs=epochs)

def encode_data(data):
    encoded_data = []

        for number in numbers:
            encoded_numbers[number - 1] = 1
        encoded_data.append(encoded_numbers)
    return np.array(encoded_data)
```

response:
Introducing Seafood Laksa - A Spicy and Delicious Soup

Are you ready to indulge in a flavorful and mouthwatering bowl of seafood laksa? In this recipe, we will explore how to make a tantalizing bowl of culinary bliss that combines fragrant spices, succulent seafood, and creamy coconut milk. In less than 30 minutes, you'll have a spicy soup that's bursting with flavor and is perfect for satisfying your cravings.

Laksa Paste and Garnish

To start with, we will prepare the laksa paste, which is the foundation of this dish. Begin by heating three tablespoons of oil in a large frying pan over medium heat. Then add a peeled and chopped onion and cook for five to six minutes until it softens. Add four medium red chilies, two teaspoons of Ginger paste, two minced cloves of garlic, a teaspoon of lemongrass paste, tablespoon of fresh coriander stalks, a teaspoon and a half of turmeric, half a teaspoon each of cumin and paprika, and a teaspoon of Tamarind paste. Mix all the ingredients together and fry them for another five minutes until they release a lovely fragrance. Once cooked, transfer the mixture to a mini chopper and blend it to form a paste.

While the laksa paste is cooking, prepare a quick and simple garnish for the soup. In a small bowl, mix a teaspoon of rice vinegar, a teaspoon of caster sugar, finely chopped red chili, a finger-sized piece of cucumber that's been finely chopped, a quarter of a small red onion that's been finely diced, and a small handful of chopped coriander leaf. Combine the ingredients until they are well-mixed, and the flavors melt together while you work on the laksa paste.

Seafood Laksa

Now that you have the laksa paste ready, add it back into the frying pan, along with 200 mL of full-fat coconut milk, a teaspoon of fish sauce, and 300 mL of chicken or seafood stock. Stir all the ingredients together and bring them to a gentle simmer. Once the sauce is heated through, add in two cod or haddock fillets weighing about 140 grams or five ounces each. Allow the fish to cook in the broth for about four minutes, stirring occasionally until the fish starts to flake apart.

As the fish cooks, soak 200 grams or about seven ounces of dried rice or vermicelli noodles in boiling water for about three minutes. Once the fish is almost cooked through, add in 16 King prawns to serve four people, and cook them for another minute until they turn pink. Next, add 200 grams or about seven ounces of fresh bean sprouts and cook them for another minute or two until they are heated through. Then turn off the heat.

To serve, drain the rice noodles and divide them between four bowls. Top the noodles with the delicious seafood laksa, and finish each bowl with a tablespoon of the fresh and vibrant garnish made earlier. Your spicy Thai-inspired soup is now ready to be enjoyed.

Required Kitchen Tools and Equipment

* Large frying pan
* Mini chopper
* Small bowl
* Wooden spoon
* Sharp knife

Tips and Variations

* Use your preferred seafood combination, such as shrimp, squid, scallops, or fish.
* Add vegetables like baby corn, sliced peppers, or bok choy to add more color and nutrition to the dish.
* Substitute chicken or vegetable stock for seafood stock if you prefer.
* Adjust the heat level by adding more or fewer chilies or using different types of chili peppers.
* Use fresh or dried noodles according to your preference.
* Add a squeeze of lime juice and a sprinkle of chopped peanuts for extra flavor.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

Portfolio Optimization Presentation Draft
OUTLINE:

In the context of Portfolio Optimization / Multi-Channel BPs, we conducted some backtesting on historical campaign data.
This backtesting consisted of measuring the accuracy of various forecast functions and the estimating the hypothetical performance improvement of various budget allocation strategies.
Our results yielded an expected increase of up to 10% more leads with as much as an expected 8.5% less Cost per Lead.

Part 1 - What we did (backtesting)
In the context of Portfolio Optimization / Multi-Channel BPs, we conducted some backtesting on historical campaign data.

Part 2 - How we did it
Forecasting - 
In order to allocate budget properly, the strategies need to be fed an accurate forecast for that period. The goal of forecasting is to predict the performance of each channel for the current (or next) period as accurately as possible using only historical data up to that point and without the benefit of hindsight (no hindsight bias). 

I used the hourly historical performance data of various campaigns from a variety of different orgs, time periods, and channels, and grouped them by various period sizes (hourly, every 6 hours, daily, etc.). Then, I paired each of several forecast functions with a range of possible lookback windows that tell the forecast functions how far back in time to look (i.e. how much recent performance changes should be weighted).

Part 2 - How we did it
Forecasting (continued) - 
Next, I generated a synthetic dataset by running every combination of forecast functions and lookback windows across all of the historical campaign performance report that I downloaded. 

Each row of this synthetic data table represents the forecasted results for one period of time of a certain historical campaign given a certain applied forecast method (a pair of a forecast function and lookback window). Each column represents an attribute relevant to either that time period, campaign, or applied forecast method.
Get rid of one of the gg functions
Gg performs better hourly because it gets rid of the zero rows but fb does better daily because there aren’t really zero rows daily and if so it’s signal not noise

Part 2 - How we did it
Forecast Results - 
Finally, I measured the overall prediction accuracy for each combination of forecast functions and lookback windows in this synthetic dataset.
Get rid of one of the gg functions
Gg performs better hourly because it gets rid of the zero rows but fb does better daily because there aren’t really zero rows daily and if so it’s signal not noise

Part 2 - How we did it
Backtesting - 
After choosing the best performance forecast function and forecasting the performance of each channel for the current period, I generated another synthetic dataset of backtest results by running every combination of budget allocation strategies and weights, which tell the strategies how aggressively to allocate budget, across the same historical campaign performance reports I used in the forecasting process. 

Again, each row of the new synthetic data table represents the backtesting results for one period of time of a certain historical campaign given a certain applied budget allocation strategy (a pair of a strategy and a weight). Each column represents an attribute relevant to either that time period, campaign, or applied strategy.

Part 2 - How we did it
Backtesting Strategies - 
Flat-weighted Budget Allocation Strategies- weights range from 10% to 40%

Flat\_Weighted\_CPL - computes forecasted CPL in each channel and allocates 50% plus a flat percentage of budget (the weight adjustment) to the outperforming channel 

Flat\_Weighted\_CTR\_CVR - same as Weighted\_CPL except it computes forecasted CTR x forecasted CVR instead
Part 2 - How we did it
Backtesting Strategies - 
Log-weighted Budget Allocation Strategies- pre-defined settings

RPS\_CPL - computes forecasted CPL in each channel relative to the average amongst all channels that time period, transforms this ratio between -1 and 1 by a log function, and allocates budget amongst the channels based on pre-defined settings (similar to the weight argument in that these settings tell the strategy how aggressively to adjust budget) that dictate budget to each channel according to the sizes of its respective log ratio

Relative\_Log\_CTR\_CVR - same as RPS\_CPL except it computes forecasted CTR x forecasted CVR instead
Part 3 - Results & Next Steps
[Results Table]

Our results yielded an expected increase of up to 10% more leads with as much as an expected 8.5% less Cost per Lead.

Expected to go live [....]

More testing coming up (hourly, more channels)

I, Tan Chee Hui (NRIC No.:830518-14-6075), Director, Shareholder and CEO of Crave Asia Sdn Bhd (Company No.: 914475-H) (hereafter referred to as "Crave Asia"), make this police report against NG CHIAN WEN (NRIC No.: 861217-23-6415) with known addresses at 19, Jalan Sri Hartamas 4, Taman Sri Hartamas, 50480 Kuala Lumpur and at No. 172, Jalan Sutera, Taman Sentosa, 80150 Johor Bahru, Johor.
I previously made two police reports against Ng Chian Wen. 
Report 1 (J/JAYA/008837/19), made on 18 September 2019 at Damansara Utama Police Station. 
• Misappropriation of company funds belonging to Crave Asia Sdn Bhd
• Forgery of company director, shareholder and CEO signatures
• Breach of trust by abusing his positions in Crave Asia Sdn Bhd
• The issuance of 38 cheques and 1 online transaction with forged signatures - amounting to RM676,085.07 (previously in first police report as RM777,228.04 – we have verified with auditor to update-to-date as today) and 9 unauthorized transaction to third parties amounting of RM66,994.60 from Crave Asia Sdn Bhd's bank account to Ng Chian Wen's personal bank account/personal usage and/or unknown payees/recipients.

Report 2 (DAMANSARA/007543/20), made on 28 June 2020 at Damasara Utama Police Station.
It revealed Ng Chian Wen's unauthorized purchase of an apartment using company funds. He also forged signatures in Sales & Purchases (S&P) related documents in order to pass through the purchases from his father-in-law, Fong Chin Tuck without any approvals, documents from the company and company secretary.
To date, the company has suffered massive losses in financial and reputation. We have discovered new findings the full extent of Ng Chian Wen's dishonesty and the harm caused to Crave Asia. These include the following:
1. After reviewing files with our Auditor, we discovered that Ng Chian Wen had hidden his fraudulent cheques by declaring them as project payments to a renovation company named BIG BRO DESIGN LANGKAWI PROJECT. However, he did not provide supporting receipts from the company. We attempted to contact BIG Bro DESIGN but were unable to do so as the company has closed and the person in charge is no longer contactable.
2. Ng Chian Wen hid this information from Crave Asia's management, accountant, auditor, and subsequently submitted falsified documents to LHDN. This resulted in LHDN imposing fines on the company and auditing the entire company. The total fines imposed by LHDN amounted to RM554,562.06.
3. As a result of the LHDN fines and blacklisting, Crave Asia suffered E-TRADE REFERENCE (ETR) degradation and was blacklisted from CTOS, which prevented the company from applying for loans, new applications, and even new phone lines from Maxis or Time Broadband.
4. Our main supplier of EPSON also stopped any credit facilities to the company, which forced us to pay 100% upfront before taking any equipment from them. This has caused significant issues for the company and future projects.
5. Our expansion plan to Singapore had to be cancelled, as the bank rejected our application due to Ng Chian Wen's fraudulent activities.

Crimes committed by Ng Chian Wen in reports 1, 2, and 3 include: 
• Forgery of cheques and bank in to own account of amounting RM676,085.07.
• Make unauthorized purchases and payments to third party or unknown companies amounting RM66,994.60.
• Deceptive actions to LHDN, created a claims including massive fines of total RM554,562.06.
• Unauthorized purchase of an apartment by tampering Sales & Purchases and relevant document.
• Tampering with bank statements to hide his fraudulent and deceptive activities from Company Management, Company Accountant, Company Auditor, LHDN, Bank, Majlis Tanah and more.
• Created massive damages and losses in reputation, financial, time and resources to the Crave Asia Sdn Bhd in past, present and future.

We request that police action be taken against Ng Chian Wen as soon as possible to ensure that justice is served and to prevent him from causing further harm to our company over the years.
Signed,
Tan Chee Hui (NRIC No.:830518-14-6075)
Director, Shareholder and CEO of Crave Asia Sdn Bhd (Company No.: 914475-H)

• The issuance of 38 cheques and 1 online transaction with forged signatures - amounting to RM676,085.07 (previously in first police report as RM777,228.04 – we have verified with auditor to update-to-date as today) and 9 unauthorized transaction to third parties amounting of RM66,994.60 from Crave Asia Sdn Bhd's bank account to Ng Chian Wen's personal bank account/personal usage and/or unknown payees/recipients.

Report 2 (DAMANSARA/007543/20), made on 28 June 2020 at Damasara Utama Police Station.
It revealed Ng Chian Wen's unauthorized purchase of an apartment using company funds. He also forged signatures in Sales & Purchases (S&P) related documents in order to pass through the purchases from his father-in-law, Fong Chin Tuck without any approvals, documents from the company and company secretary.
To date, the company has suffered massive losses in financial and reputation. We have discovered new findings the full extent of Ng Chian Wen's dishonesty and the harm caused to Crave Asia. These include the following:
1. After reviewing files with our Auditor, we discovered that Ng Chian Wen had hidden his fraudulent cheques by declaring them as project payments to a renovation company named BIG BRO DESIGN LANGKAWI PROJECT. However, he did not provide supporting receipts from the company. We attempted to contact BIG Bro DESIGN but were unable to do so as the company has closed and the person in charge is no longer contactable.
2. Ng Chian Wen hid this information from Crave Asia's management, accountant, auditor, and subsequently submitted falsified documents to LHDN. This resulted in LHDN imposing fines on the company and auditing the entire company. The total fines imposed by LHDN amounted to RM554,562.06.
3. As a result of the LHDN fines and blacklisting, Crave Asia suffered E-TRADE REFERENCE (ETR) degradation and was blacklisted from CTOS, which prevented the company from applying for loans, new applications, and even new phone lines from Maxis or Time Broadband.
4. Our main supplier of EPSON also stopped any credit facilities to the company, which forced us to pay 100% upfront before taking any equipment from them. This has caused significant issues for the company and future projects.
5. Our expansion plan to Singapore had to be cancelled, as the bank rejected our application due to Ng Chian Wen's fraudulent activities.

Crimes committed by Ng Chian Wen in reports 1, 2, and 3 include: 
• Forgery of cheques and bank in to own account of amounting RM676,085.07.
• Make unauthorized purchases and payments to third party or unknown companies amounting RM66,994.60.
• Deceptive actions to LHDN, created a claims including massive fines of total RM554,562.06.
• Unauthorized purchase of an apartment by tampering Sales & Purchases and relevant document.
• Tampering with bank statements to hide his fraudulent and deceptive activities from Company Management, Company Accountant, Company Auditor, LHDN, Bank, Majlis Tanah and more.
• Created massive damages and losses in reputation, financial, time and resources to the Crave Asia Sdn Bhd in past, present and future.

We request that police action be taken against Ng Chian Wen as soon as possible to ensure that justice is served and to prevent him from causing further harm to our company over the years.

prompt:
You are a strategist for a political campaigner. 

"I am currently a Lecturer in Social Policy in the Department of Applied Social Studies in Maynooth. I teach courses at post-graduate and under-graduate level in housing, rights and inequality; civic engagement and civil society; the changing nature of the welfare state; and climate, social policy and inequality. 
I have researched and published in academic and policy fields of housing and social housing, spatial disadvantage, housing rights, economic inequality, neoliberalism and the welfare state, social justice, and social movements. I have a PhD in political and economic geography from Trinity College Dublin in 2009. 
My most recent publication is the book, 'Housing Shock: The Irish Housing Crisis and How to Solve it' (Policy Press, 2020). It is a highly original book that was the first in Ireland to identify the emergence of Generation Rent, the distorting role of global investor funds in Irish housing, the profoundly damaging impact of homelessness on families, and identifying new solutions based on a based human rights vision for Irish housing and a practical policy pathway to ensure affordable, secure, decent quality and environmentally sustainable homes for everyone. It tackles one of the most pressing social crises facing contemporary Ireland. It makes a compelling case for enshrining the Right to Housing in our Constitution. It is written in a highly accessible, passionate way, that details the author’s personal journey from community worker to academic and activist and how his housing story interwove with his commitment and drive to achieve a human right to housing for everyone ins this country. The book is highly inspirational as it is not just as description of the crisis, but also provides direct voices of those affected, outlines solutions and offers pathways for citizens to engage in action to change the situation. In a short space of time the book has made a major contribution to the Irish policy debate on housing and to empowering those affected by the crisis and those trying to change it. The President of Ireland, in recognition of this contribution as a scholarly resource of national importance, invited the author to present the book to him personally in Aras an Uachtarain in June 2021. An academic review in the international journal Critical Social Policy describes the book as “a highly welcome and thoughtful addition to the debate about housing in Ireland, drawing on comparative examples, quantitative and qualitative data, and his engagement with the topic as both researcher and activist to do so”. 
While Leilani Farha, Global Director of the Shift and former UN Rapporteur on Adequate Housing 2014-2020, describes the book as providing a really important and insightful contribution to the global debate on financialisation, inequality and the right to housing.” The Irish Times described it as “a valuable book. It is a tool for better understanding our current predicament and what we can do about it”. 
In 2011 I published an academic peer
reviewed book, ‘Public Private
Partnerships in Ireland; Failed experiment or the way forward?’ (Manchester
University Press in 2011). 
I have also published in high quality international peer reviewed journals. For example, drawing from praxis-based research on ‘the right to the city’ and human rights based approaches (undertaken as a community worker in Dolphin House, Dublin from 2007 to 2013) I have published in the international Journal of Human Rights Practice, Human Geography, and the Irish Journal of Community Work. While I have published on my innovative research into new social movements and civil society in Ireland in Interface, and in Geoforum
Over
2015-2017, I was a Senior Policy Analyst with the inequality research think
tank, TASC where I researched the political economy of economic inequality and
the welfare state, with a particular focus on housing, financialisation, social
policy and inequality. I was lead author of Cherishing
All Equally 2016: Economic Inequality in Ireland and ‘Home
or wealth generator? Inequality, financialisation and the Irish Housing crisis’ (TASC, 2017). 
I worked between 2017 and 2018 on the H2020 funded Re-InVEST (Rebuilding an Inclusive, Value-based Europe
of Solidarity and Trust through Social Investments) project. It involved research (qualitative
and quantitative) into EU and national state social policy (in the water,
housing, finance, childcare and early childhood education, labour market, and
health sectors) across 13 EU countries. I co-developed, with the Irish Principal Investigator
on Re-InVEST, Dr Mary Murphy, the Re-InVEST project’s methodological approach,
the Participatory Action Human Rights and
Capabilities Approach (PAHRCA), and the PAHRCA Toolkit. 
I am also a public intellectual and regularly contribute to discussion of contemporary social, economic and political issues on national media and contribute to public events dealing with these issues."
response:
Based on your extensive background in social policy, housing, and economic inequality, I would recommend the following strategy for your political campaign:

1. Establish a clear, concise platform: Your platform should focus on the issues that matter most to you and where you have expertise, such as housing, economic inequality, and social justice. Develop clear policy proposals to address these issues, including the right to housing, affordable housing, and addressing spatial disadvantage.
2. Build a strong narrative: Connect your personal journey from community worker to academic and activist to your political campaign. Emphasize your commitment to creating a more just and equitable society, and use stories from your research and personal experience to illustrate the real-world impact of the issues you're addressing.
3. Engage with grassroots movements and community organizations: Collaborate with local groups working on housing, social justice, and inequality issues. These partnerships can help amplify your message, mobilize supporters, and provide valuable insights from the community.
4. Utilize your academic and policy expertise: Highlight your research and publications as evidence of your deep understanding of the issues at hand. Use your experience working on EU and national social policy projects to demonstrate your ability to navigate complex policy environments and deliver results.
5. Position yourself as a thought leader: Continue contributing to public discussions on social, economic, and political issues through media appearances, op-eds, and public events. Use these opportunities to emphasize your policy proposals and build your reputation as a knowledgeable and passionate advocate for change.
6. Build a strong campaign team: Assemble a diverse team of experts and advocates who share your vision for a more equitable society. This team should include individuals with experience in policy, communications, grassroots organizing, and fundraising.
7. Leverage endorsements: Seek endorsements from respected figures in academia, social policy, and activism, as well as individuals directly affected by the issues you're addressing. These endorsements can provide credibility and help broaden your appeal to voters.
8. Engage with voters: Make an effort to connect with voters through town halls, community events, and social media. Listen to their concerns and be responsive to their needs. Use these interactions to refine your policy proposals and strengthen your message.
9. Focus on key demographics: Target your campaign messaging and outreach efforts towards demographics most affected by the issues you're addressing, such as low-income households, renters, and marginalized communities.
10. Stay adaptable and resilient: Be prepared to face challenges and adapt your campaign strategy as needed. Stay true to your vision and maintain a focus on the issues that matter most to you and the communities you aim to serve.

response:
I apologize for the confusion. The issue is still with the edge\_index tensor. We need to make sure the edge\_index tensor has the correct dimensions for the batched graph. Let's modify the edge\_index construction to account for the batched structure of the graph:
```python
edge_index = torch.cat(
    [torch.randint(0, num_nodes, (2, num_edges)) + i * num_nodes for i in range(batch_size)],
    dim=1,
)
```
This will create an edge\_index tensor compatible with the batched graph.

Here is the revised script:
```python
import torch
import torch.nn as nn
import torch_geometric as pyg
import torch_geometric.data as pyg_data

class EdgeConv2DGCNConv(pyg.nn.MessagePassing):
    def __init__(self, in_channels, out_channels):
        super().__init__(aggr='add')
        self.lin = nn.Linear(in_channels, out_channels)
        self.conv = nn.Conv2d(in_channels, out_channels, kernel_size=3, padding=1)

    def forward(self, x, edge_index, edge_attr):
        return self.propagate(edge_index, x=x, edge_attr=edge_attr)

    def message(self, x_j, edge_attr):
        x_j = self.conv(x_j)
        edge_attr = self.lin(edge_attr.unsqueeze(-1).unsqueeze(-1))
        return x_j * edge_attr

class GNNClassifier(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self, in_channels, hidden_channels, num_classes):
        super().__init__()
        self.gnn = EdgeConv2DGCNConv(in_channels, hidden_channels)
        self.fc = nn.Linear(hidden_channels, num_classes)

    def forward(self, data):
        x, edge_index, edge_attr = data.x, data.edge_index, data.edge_attr
        x = self.gnn(x, edge_index, edge_attr)
        x = torch.relu(x)
        x = x.mean(dim=(2, 3))  # Global average pooling for image-like features
        x = self.fc(x)
        return x

num_nodes = 10
num_edges = 50
in_channels = 16
hidden_channels = 32
num_classes = 4
batch_size = 2

x = torch.randn(batch_size, num_nodes, in_channels, 3, 3)
edge_attr = torch.randn(batch_size, num_edges, in_channels)
batch = torch.zeros(num_nodes * batch_size, dtype=torch.long)

# Create the correct edge_index tensor for the batched graph
edge_index = torch.cat(
    [torch.randint(0, num_nodes, (2, num_edges)) + i * num_nodes for i in range(batch_size)],
    dim=1,
)

data = pyg_data.Batch.from_data_list(
    [pyg_data.Data(x=x[i], edge_index=edge_index, edge_attr=edge_attr[i]) for i in range(batch_size)]
)
data.batch = batch

model = GNNClassifier(in_channels, hidden_channels, num_classes)

output = model(data)

print(output)
```
This should resolve the IndexError. The dimensionality of edge attributes for a GNN with N nodes would depend on the specific problem and data representation. In this case, we have `num_edges` edges, and each edge has `in_channels` features.

```python
)

data = pyg_data.Batch.from_data_list(
    [pyg_data.Data(x=x[i], edge_index=edge_index, edge_attr=edge_attr[i]) for i in range(batch_size)]
)
data.batch = batch

model = GNNClassifier(in_channels, hidden_channels, num_classes)

output = model(data)

print(output)
```
This should resolve the IndexError. The dimensionality of edge attributes for a GNN with N nodes would depend on the specific problem and data representation. In this case, we have `num_edges` edges, and each edge has `in_channels` features.

Overall, these JavaScript coding games are a great way to practice your coding skills and have fun while doing it.

3a|Application Installation|Application Build|Oracle AMS Build|10 days|3/8|3/21|
3b|Application Installation|Operational Acceptance|AMS|10 days|3/22|4/4|
3c|Application Installation|Marriott Opera customization|AMS|10 days|3/22|4/4|
3d|Application Installation|Marriott tasks - N/A|Marriott|NA|NA|NA|
4a|Network Connectivity to Environments|Fast Connect decision or TIP|Marriott|TBD|1/23|TBD|

4c|Network Connectivity to Environments|Whitelist IPs (if Fast Connect)|Marriott|TBD|TBD|TBD|4a
4d|Network Connectivity to Environments|Confirm Certificate requirements (if applicable)|Marriott|TBD|TBD|TBD|4a
4e|Network Connectivity to Environments|Confirm connectivity based on Peering document|Oracle/Marriott|TBD|TBD|TBD|4a
5a|OHIP and Report and Analytics Installation|OHIP Integration|AMS Operations|15 days|4/5|4/25|
5b|OHIP and Report and Analytics Installation|RNA (Report and Analytics) Integration |PMO/RNA Dev|15 days|4/5|4/25|
6a|Environment Readiness & validation|Confirm Application installation with Test Resort that will be removed upon completion|Environment Readiness|5 days|4/26|5/2|
6b|Environment Readiness & validation|Release notifications sent to Oracle Project team|Environment Readiness|5 days|4/26|5/2|
7a|MMF | OIC (Oracle Integration Cloud) Connectivity|Confirm connectivity along with Marriott|Oracle/Marriott|5 days|4/26|5/2|

8a|Resort creation|Complete SURA section and SAR forms on Order # 40640825|Sales|TBD|TBD|TBD|1c
8b|Resort creation|Provisioning team completes Resort creation|Provisioning|3 days|5/3|5/5|
8a|Resort creation|Provide Opera Dashboard URLs|Provisioning|3 days|5/3|5/5|
8b|Resort creation|Marriott to connect to Opera using the Dashboard URLs|Marriott|TBD|TBD|TBD|
9a|SSD / Federation|Create roles in OPERA, SSD, and IDP|Professional Services|5 days|5/8|5/12|
9b|SSD / Federation|Provide Metadata to Oracle|Marriott|TBD|TBD|TBD|
10a|Resort configuration|Create Groups and Permissions|Marriott|TBD|TBD|TBD|
10b|Resort configuration|Opera controls configuration|Marriott|TBD|TBD|TBD|
10c|Resort configuration|Opera Resort configuration|Marriott|TBD|TBD|TBD|
11a|Marriott Interface configuration|Marriott to provide finalized end points|Marriott|5 days|5/15|5/19|
11b|Marriott Interface configuration|Oracle to configure finalized end points|Consulting Delivery|5 days|5/15|5/19|

1. Operational acceptance completed.

response:
It seems like some of the values in the JSON are not being parsed correctly, resulting in null values. One possible issue could be that some of the fields are of type `VARCHAR` instead of `DOUBLE` or `INTEGER`, causing issues when casting to numeric types.

To fix this, you can try explicitly casting the problematic fields to their correct types in the `SELECT` statement, like so:
```sql
CREATE STREAM raw_receipts
  (_id STRUCT<oid VARCHAR, copyingData BOOLEAN>,
   operationType VARCHAR,
   documentKey STRUCT<_id STRUCT<oid VARCHAR>>,
   fullDocument STRUCT<_id STRUCT<oid VARCHAR>,
                       AMOUNT_PAID DOUBLE,
                       ADDRESS VARCHAR,
                       VENDOR_PHONE VARCHAR,
                       VENDOR_NAME VARCHAR,
                       INVOICE_RECEIPT_DATE VARCHAR,
                       SUBTOTAL DOUBLE,
                       TAX DOUBLE,
                       TOTAL DOUBLE,
                       url VARCHAR,
                       Time VARCHAR>,
   ns STRUCT<db VARCHAR, coll VARCHAR>)
  WITH (KAFKA_TOPIC='realtimedb.reciepts', VALUE_FORMAT='JSON') AS
  SELECT _id->'_id'->>'$oid' AS oid,
         copyingData,
         operationType,
         documentKey->'_id'->>'$oid' AS document_id,
         CAST(fullDocument->'AMOUNT_PAID' AS DOUBLE) AS AMOUNT_PAID,
         fullDocument->'ADDRESS' AS ADDRESS,
         fullDocument->'VENDOR_PHONE' AS VENDOR_PHONE,
         fullDocument->'VENDOR_NAME' AS VENDOR_NAME,
         fullDocument->'INVOICE_RECEIPT_DATE' AS INVOICE_RECEIPT_DATE,
         CAST(fullDocument->'SUBTOTAL' AS DOUBLE) AS SUBTOTAL,
         CAST(fullDocument->'TAX' AS DOUBLE) AS TAX,
         CAST(fullDocument->'TOTAL' AS DOUBLE) AS TOTAL,
         fullDocument->'url' AS url,
         fullDocument->'Time' AS Time,
         ns
  FROM realtimedb.reciepts;
```
This should ensure that the problematic fields are properly casted to their correct types, and should eliminate the null values in the resulting stream.

Hello there! As a hair stylist who is an expert in managing frizzy hair, I'm excited to share some light-hearted tips and tricks to help you manage your frizz and achieve fabulous, frizz-free locks. Let's get started!

1. What causes frizzy hair?

Frizz is caused by a lack of moisture in the hair. When the hair is dry and lacks moisture, the hair cuticles lift and cause the hair to become frizzy. Humidity and heat can also contribute to frizz, as they can cause the hair to absorb moisture from the air and swell, which leads to frizz.

2. How to style frizzy hair.

Styling frizzy hair can be a challenge, but there are some tricks you can use to make your hair look great. To start, use a wide-tooth comb or a detangling brush to gently comb out your hair while it's still damp. This will help to minimize tangles and prevent breakage. For curly hair, use a diffuser attachment on your blow dryer to help define curls and reduce frizz. If you have straight hair, try using a round brush while blow drying to smooth the hair and reduce frizz.

3. How to dry frizzy hair.

Drying frizzy hair can be a challenge, but there are some techniques you can use to help reduce frizz. Avoid rubbing your hair with a towel, as this can cause friction and lead to frizz. Instead, gently blot your hair with a microfiber towel or an old t-shirt to remove excess moisture. If you have curly hair, try plopping your hair with a t-shirt or microfiber towel to help define curls and reduce frizz. For straight hair, try air-drying or blow-drying with a cool setting to help smooth the hair and reduce frizz.

4. What devices help manage frizzy hair?

There are a few devices that can help manage frizzy hair. One of the best devices for managing frizz is a hair dryer with an ionizing feature. Ionic hair dryers emit negative ions that help to break up water molecules and reduce frizz. The Jinri Paris Professional Infrared Ion Salon Dryer is a great option for managing frizzy hair. It's lightweight and equipped with advanced far-infrared and negative ionic technologies that maintain hair moisture and make it silky smooth. The dryer also protects your hair from damage and dullness.

5. What products help manage frizzy hair?

There are a variety of products that can help manage frizzy hair. For starters, try using a hair serum or oil to help lock in moisture and reduce frizz. The Desert Beauty Premium Quality Argan Oil is a great option that's enriched with jojoba oil, coconut oil, and other natural ingredients that provide extra nourishment to your hair. If you have curly hair, try using a curl activator like the MopTop Curly Hair Custard Gel. It enhances the structure of wavy to kinky hair, adds definition, texture, and a natural sheen to the hair. The formula contains aloe vera, nettle, silk amino acids, sea botanicals, and honey, which offer maximum hold while moisturizing the hair.

I hope these tips and product recommendations help you manage your frizzy hair and achieve the beautiful, frizz-free locks you deserve! If you have any further questions, feel free to ask.

nance of any report filed or required to be
filed pursuant to this Act, or any regula-
tion, order, direction, mitigation measure,
prohibition, or other authorization or direc-
tive issued thereunder.
(F) No person may engage in any trans-
action or take any other action with intent to
evade the provisions of this Act, or any regula-
tion, order, direction, mitigation measure, pro-
hibition, or other authorization or directive
issued thereunder.
(G) No person may fail or refuse to comply
with any reporting or recordkeeping require-
ment of this Act, or any regulation, order, di-

rection, mitigation measure, prohibition, or
other authorization or directive issued there-
under.
(H) Except as specifically authorized in
this subchapter, any regulation, order, direc-
tion, mitigation measure, or other authorization
or directive issued thereunder or in writing by
the Department of Commerce, no person may
alter any order, direction, mitigation measure,
or other authorization or directive issued under
this Act or any related regulation.
(3) Additional requirements.—
(A) CONTINUATION OF EFFECT.—For pur-
poses of paragraph (2)(E), any representation,
statement, or certification made by any person
shall be deemed to be continuing in effect until
the person notifies the Department of Com-
merce or relevant executive department or agen-
cy in accordance with subparagraph (B).
(B) NOTIFICATION.—Any person who
makes a representation, statement, or certifi-
cation to the Department of Commerce or any
official of any other executive department or
agency relating to any order, direction, mitiga-
tion measure, prohibition, or other authorization
Read.

prompt:
Primary setting: The Luxian Empire
The Luxian Empire is a vast alien empire spanning more than half of its galaxy. Lux, the homeworld of the Luxite species, serves as the empire’s capital. Between 10-20 habitable planets house varying numbers of Luxian citizens spread throughout the galaxy. The Luxian society is technologically advanced and is ruled by an empress, who has absolute power over all aspects of life in the empire.

The Luxians are very technologically advanced. They have developed advanced weapons, perfected faster-than-light travel and teleportation (though on a small scale), eradicated many diseases, established very efficient public services, and incorporated advanced technology into every facet of life from hobbies to government operations. Even their architecture takes advantage of their discoveries and inventions to achieve previously impossible structures or designs.

This technological advancement has a dark side, however. Luxians are also obsessed with perfection and believe themselves, as a species and a civilization, to be perfect. Individuals feel this pressure as much as the society itself does. Anything that hinders their perfection must be suppressed or eliminated. Consequently, cosmetic habits - makeup, plastic surgery, mood-altering medications, specialized hair care, unique inventions (like contact lenses that make your eyes look “normal” if they are red or puffy) - are in high demand, although most Luxians don’t talk about using them because no one enjoys admitting that they need them.

The Luxians are also known for their strict laws and their belief in their own racial superiority. They do not tolerate peaceful coexistence with other alien nations for long. They believe they will ultimately dominate the galaxy, and see other civilizations as barriers to their advancement - barriers that must be destroyed.

The Luxians have a strong military, and they use their power and resources to conquer and wipe out other civilizations. The alien species that once made up those civilizations are reduced to mere slaves in the empire. Some work as servants, serving a Luxian master directly. Many others are forced to work in the empire’s mines, factories, and other industries. These slaves are treated poorly and have few rights, and they live in constant fear of punishment and abuse. While abolitionist groups and individuals do champion for the rights of aliens, slaves in the empire have functionally no rights and no legal path to freedom.

It’s been hundreds of years since the last time the Luxians found and conquered another civilization. In that time, the remnants of the enslaved aliens’ former cultures - language, traditions, religions - have all but been wiped out by Luxian oppression. Alien children are even raised apart from their parents in Luxian-run facilities known as “nurseries”, where the children are trained to serve future masters before being sold. The Luxians take great care to ensure their slaves have no memory of their people’s former lives.

The Luxians are also a very atheistic society. Their species has not had a religion of any sort for many generations now, as they believe they are the pinnacle of existence and the existence of any gods would be a threat to their perfection. Consequently, religion is highly discouraged among the Luxian citizens. A few believe in a New-Age-like universal consciousness, but that is about as religious as Luxians ever get. For slaves - many of whom come from religious societies - religion is outright forbidden and punished harshly. The Luxians tend to care less if the slaves adopt some of their New Age beliefs, however.

Overall, the Luxian Empire is a ruthless and oppressive society that values power and control above all else. Its ruling class is wealthy and privileged, while its lower classes (particularly aliens) are oppressed and enslaved. 
Luxians/Luxites
“Luxian” is the nationality belonging to the Luxian Empire. “Luxite” is the dominant species of the empire, originating from their homeworld, Lux.

Luxites are tall, elegant humanoid creatures with long hair and large eyes. They average between 6-7 feet in height and live up to 120-150 years, and age proportionately. Their skin, hair, and eyes come in varying shades of pink, purple, and lavender. Both the men and the women have long, thick hair: the men tend to grow their hair out to shoulder length or slightly below, while the women grow their hair out at least to waist length, and often longer. Many Luxians see their hair as a symbol of their perfection and are obsessed with keeping it healthy and well-groomed.

Luxians typically wear clothing comparable to traditional Indian garb. The men wear long, tunic-like tops and loose trousers. The women wear long skirts or pants with a crop top and flowing sashes or scarves, or sometimes a single-piece dress with an accompanying scarf. When necessary, they wear simpler clothing more optimized for space travel. Their military uniforms consist of black with silver accents, with additional markings for high-ranking officers. Royal guards wear a fancier version of the standard military uniform.
response: Thank you for providing this background information. It gives me a good understanding of the Luxian Empire and the society within it. Do you have a specific question about your story or would you like general guidance on where to take it?
